questions.text: Which of the following movements of the mandible involves the involvement of the inferior compartment of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Elevation
 
  • The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is a complex joint responsible for the movement of the mandible (lower jaw).
  • It consists of two compartments: the superior compartment and the inferior compartment.
  • The inferior compartment of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is involved in the rotational movement of the mandible, which is known as elevation. This is the movement of the mandible when the mouth closes.
  • The other choices, protrusion, retraction, and translation, are all movements that involve the superior compartment of the TMJ.





Reference: https://www.physio-pedia.com/TMJ_Anatomy

questions.text: Which of these is accurate regarding the space pointed by green arrow in the given figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Breath sound can be heard more clearly 

The marked arrow indicates the triangle of auscultation.
The marked area is the triangle of auscultation.
Boundaries include-
• Medially by the lateral border of the inferior part of trapezius.
• Laterally by the vertebral border of the scapula.
• Inferiorly by the superior border of latissimus dorsi muscle.
Importance-
• Only part of back which is covered by muscles.
• Respiratory sounds are better heard when ausculted here.
The triangle of auscultation refers to a specific anatomical region on the human body where lung sounds can be best heard. It is an area where there is less muscle and fat coverage, allowing for clearer auscultation of respiratory sounds. Here’s how you can locate it:

  • Position: Stand or sit comfortably with your back exposed.

  • Location: The triangle itself is located roughly between the scapula (shoulder blade) and the latissimus dorsi muscle. Specifically, it is an imaginary triangle-shaped area with its base along the bottom edge of the scapula and its apex pointing towards the lower ribs.

  • Purpose: This area is important for auscultation (listening with a stethoscope) because the underlying lung tissue is closer to the surface here, allowing healthcare providers to hear respiratory sounds such as normal breathing sounds (vesicular breath sounds) or abnormal sounds like crackles or wheezes more clearly.

  • In clinical practice, this region is particularly useful for detecting abnormalities in lung sounds and for assessing respiratory function in patients.



    Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 843,852

choices.text: Menisci are made up of elastic cartilage

questions.text: Which of these is accurate regarding the menisci of knee joint:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:Medial meniscus covers the most of the articular surface of proximal tibia

 

Each knee joint contains two menisci, which are crescent-shaped fibrocartilaginous structures located between the femur (thigh bone) and the tibia (shin bone). They sit atop the tibial plateau and deepen the joint surface, contributing to its stability. Medial meniscus covers most of the articular surface of proximal tibia. Menisci are fibro-cartilage with the peripheral portion vascular and lateral meniscus is more mobile.
MEDIAL MENISCUS :

  1. Location: The medial meniscus is situated on the inner side of the knee joint, between the medial condyle of the femur (thigh bone) and the medial condyle of the tibia (shin bone).

  2. Shape: It is semicircular or crescent-shaped, thicker at the periphery and thinner towards the center.

  3. Attachments:

    • The peripheral rim of the medial meniscus is firmly attached to the joint capsule and blends with the fibers of the medial collateral ligament (MCL).
    • It is also attached to the tibial plateau through coronary ligaments, which stabilize its position.

  4. Clinical Considerations:

Injuries: The medial meniscus is more prone to injury compared to the lateral meniscus due to its anatomical attachments and less mobility. Injuries can occur from sudden twisting motions, sports activities, or degenerative changes over time.

Tears: Common types of tears include longitudinal tears, bucket-handle tears (where a portion flips into the joint), and complex tears involving both the outer rim and inner portion.

Treatment: Treatment for medial meniscus tears depends on the type and severity of the injury. Options range from conservative management (rest, ice, physical therapy) to surgical interventions such as meniscectomy (partial removal) or meniscal repair (suturing the torn meniscus.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no  1406

Anatomy:

  1. Origin: The genitofemoral nerve arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves within the lumbar plexus.

  2. Course: After its origin, the nerve descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from its lateral border.

    • Femoral Branch (or Femoral Component)

Function:

  • Sensory Innervation: The sensory branch of the Genitofemoral nerve supplies the skin of the upper anterior thigh (femoral branch) and the skin over the scrotum or labia majora (genital branch).
  • Motor Innervation :The motor branch of the Genitofemoral nerve innervates the cremaster muscle in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

questions.text: Select the extraocular muscle that causes lateral movement [abduction] and elevation of eye ball.
questions.solution:
Correct Option 2:Inferior oblique
  • The extraocular muscle responsible for causing lateral abduction and elevation of the eyeball is the inferior oblique muscle.
  • This muscle is one of the six muscles that control the movements of the eye and is responsible for rotating the eye upward and outward (lateral abduction) when it contracts.
EXTRAOCCULAR MUSCLES AND MOVEMENTS :

  • Medial Rectus Muscle: Located on the nasal side of the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye medially (towards the nose), causing adduction (moving the eye inward).

  • Lateral Rectus Muscle: Located on the temporal side of the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye laterally (towards the temple), causing abduction (moving the eye outward).

  • Superior Rectus Muscle: Located above the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye upward, causing elevation (moving the eye upward) and slight adduction.

  • Inferior Rectus Muscle: Located below the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye downward, causing depression (moving the eye downward) and slight adduction.

  • Superior Oblique Muscle: Originating from the back of the orbit, it passes through a pulley-like structure (trochlea) before inserting on the sclera. When it contracts, it primarily rotates the eye downward and laterally (extorsion).

  • Inferior Oblique Muscle: Originating from the orbital floor near the nose, it inserts on the sclera near the lateral rectus muscle. When it contracts, it primarily rotates the eye upward and laterally (intorsion).



    Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 774

  1. Main sensory nucleus (or principal sensory nucleus): This nucleus receives fine touch, pressure, and proprioceptive sensory information from the face.
  2. Spinal nucleus (or spinal trigeminal nucleus): This nucleus receives pain and temperature sensory information from the face.

choices.text: Flow of local current in retrograde direction

questions.text: Action potential propagation in neurons is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Sideway movement of Na+ intracellularly
 
  • The nerve cell membrane is polarized at rest, with positive charges lined up along the outside of the membrane and negative charges along the inside.
  • During the action potential, this polarity is abolished and for a brief period is actually reversed.
  • Voltage-gated Na+ channels are highly concentrated in the nodes of Ranvier and the initial segment in myelinated neurons. depolarization in myelinated axons travels from one node of Ranvier to the next. This “jumping” of depolarization from node to node is called saltatory conduction
  • In the natural situation, impulses pass in one direction only, from synaptic junctions or receptors along axons to their termination. Such conduction is called orthodromic. Conduction in the opposite direction is called antidromic. Because synapses permit conduction in one direction only, an antidromic impulse will fail to pass the first synapse they encounter and die out at that point.
  • Calcium ions (Ca2+) also play a role in neuronal signaling, but they are primarily involved in other processes such as neurotransmitter release and synaptic transmission. While Ca2+ does not directly contribute to action potential propagation, it is important for synaptic activity and the modulation of neuronal function.
  • Thus out of the given options, Sideways movement of intracellular sodium propagates AP seems to be the correct option.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 87,88

questions.text: Why is the conduction of nerve impulse at the synapse unidirectional?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2

Dendrites and body have no neurotransmitter hence at synapse nerve impulse transmission is unidirectional.
Option 4:- Na+ channels can open in only one direction only is the explanation for nerve impulse conduction being unidirectional. 

The unidirectional conduction in a chemical synapse is achieved through several mechanisms:

  • Presynaptic Neuron: This is the neuron that sends the signal. When an action potential (nerve impulse) reaches the axon terminal of the presynaptic neuron, it triggers the release of neurotransmitter molecules from synaptic vesicles into the synaptic cleft.

  • Synaptic Cleft: This is the tiny gap between the axon terminal of the presynaptic neuron and the dendrite or cell body of the postsynaptic neuron.

  • Postsynaptic Neuron: This is the neuron that receives the signal. The neurotransmitter molecules released into the synaptic cleft bind to specific receptors on the membrane of the postsynaptic neuron.

  • Ion Channels and Depolarization: When neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the postsynaptic neuron, they can cause ion channels to open, allowing ions (such as sodium or potassium) to flow into or out of the postsynaptic neuron. This generates a postsynaptic potential, which can either be excitatory (depolarizing) or inhibitory (hyperpolarizing), depending on the type of neurotransmitter and receptor involved.




 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 122

questions.text: PaO2 (Arterial) is not decreased in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Congestive heart failure without Pulmonary edema
  • The partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is a measure of the amount of oxygen dissolved in the blood.
  • The question asks which of the given conditions does not cause a decrease in PaO2. Option 2, congestive heart failure, is the correct answer. In congestive heart failure, the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. This can lead to fluid buildup in the lungs, causing shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. However, it does not directly affect the amount of oxygen in the blood, and therefore does not cause a decrease in PaO2.
  • Option 1, restrictive lung disease, refers to a group of lung diseases that restrict lung expansion, making it difficult to breathe. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen exchange in the lungs.
  • Option 3, obstructive lung disease, refers to a group of lung diseases that obstruct airflow, making it difficult to exhale. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen exchange in the lungs.
  • Option 4, high altitude, refers to a condition where there is a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to lower atmospheric pressure at high altitudes. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen availability.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545153/

questions.text: Which of the following claims about enzymes that have cooperative substrate binding is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Value of Km is invalid

Allosteric enzymes are characterized by modulation of their activity with the help of a modifier/effector at the substrate biding/active site.
Modifier can either by a positive modifier which increases catalytic activity and a negative modifier which decreases catalytic activity.
Features of allosteric enzymes-
  • Multi subunit enzymes which possess a quaternary structure.
  • Modifier does not necessarily has to be a structural analogue of the substrate.
  • Due to property of co-operative binding ( where binding of one substrate favors binding of other substrates to same enzyme like hemoglobin ) , they exhibit sigmoid kinetics.
  • Substrate saturation curve is therefore, a sigmoid curve.
  • Do not follow Michaelis-Menten hyperbolic kinetics which results in a hyperbolic curve. Therefore, Km in invalid.

Here's a simplified comparison of normal enzyme kinetics versus cooperative binding:

Aspect Normal Enzyme Kinetics Cooperative Binding
Definition Enzyme binds substrate independently. Substrate binding affects the binding of additional substrates.
Kinetics Graph Follows a hyperbolic curve (Michaelis-Menten). Shows a sigmoidal curve (S-shaped). Doesn't follow Michaelis Menten curve
Substrate Affinity Constant affinity, independent of substrate amount. Affinity changes as substrates bind (positive/negative cooperativity).
Key Concept Substrate binding doesn't influence other binding sites. Binding at one site enhances or reduces affinity at others.
Examples Most enzymes (e.g., hexokinase, chymotrypsin). Hemoglobin (positive cooperativity); allosteric enzymes.
Regulation Primarily regulated by inhibitors or activators. Often regulated by allosteric effectors (e.g., ATP, H+).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 76.

questions.text: Pyrimidine nucleotides are synthesized in salvage pathway of Pyrimidine synthesis through:
questions.solution:
Correct option 3:Both pyrimidine bases and nucleosides 
  • Pyrimidine nucleotides are synthesized through the salvage pathway of pyrimidine synthesis via both pyrimidine bases and nucleosides.
  • The salvage pathway is an important pathway for the synthesis of nucleotides, as it allows the reuse of nucleobases and nucleosides that are generated during the degradation of RNA and DNA.
  • In the salvage pathway, the free pyrimidine bases and nucleosides are converted into the corresponding nucleotides through the addition of a phosphate group, which is derived from ATP.
  • The enzymes involved in the salvage pathway are specific for pyrimidine bases and nucleosides, and they differ from those involved in de novo pyrimidine synthesis.
  • This pathway is energetically favorable, as it requires less ATP than the de novo pathway.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 342.

  • Thyroxine hormone is produced by the thyroid gland and is involved in the regulation of metabolism. It affects various processes in the body, including the electron transport chain (ETC), which is responsible for the production of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) - the energy currency of the cell.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because although thyroxine hormone does stimulate the ETC, it does not specifically stimulate it to generate heat and energy. The ETC is always involved in the production of ATP, which is a form of energy.
  • Option 2 is incorrect because thyroxine hormone does not inhibit the ETC by inhibiting complex 1. In fact, thyroxine hormone increases the activity of the ETC by increasing the activity of complex IV.
  • Option 3 is correct because thyroxine hormone inhibits ATP formation by inhibiting the phosphorylation of ADP. This means that although the ETC may still be active, the production of ATP is reduced because ADP is not being converted to ATP. Thyroxine is a physiological uncoupler.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because as mentioned earlier, thyroxine hormone does affect the ETC by increasing its activity through complex IV.
  • In summary, the correct option is 3 because thyroxine hormone inhibits ATP formation by inhibiting the phosphorylation of ADP.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 128.

questions.text: Which category of carbohydrates does fructose belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Ketose monosaccharide

Fructose is a ketose monosaccharide, meaning it contains a ketone functional group (C=O) within its structure. 

  1. Chemical Structure: Fructose has the molecular formula C6H12O6 and the same empirical formula (CH2O)n as glucose and other monosaccharides. However, its structure differs in the positioning of the carbonyl group.

  2. Ketose vs. Aldose: Monosaccharides are classified based on the position of their carbonyl group (either an aldehyde or a ketone group). In fructose, the carbonyl group is a ketone, located on the second carbon atom of the molecule.

  3. Sweetness: Fructose is notably sweeter than glucose, which is one reason why it's commonly used as a sweetener in various foods and beverages.

  4. Sources: It naturally occurs in fruits (hence its name, which is derived from Latin "fructus" meaning fruit) and is also found in honey and some vegetables.

Metabolism: Fructose is metabolized differently than glucose. It is primarily metabolized in the liver, where it can be converted into glucose or stored as glycogen.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 536.148

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has swollen tonsils, a sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The following image depicts the removed tonsil's histological features. What is the responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) EBV
 
  • The histological features of swollen tonsils, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The image provided shows characteristic histological findings of infectious mononucleosis, including hyperplastic germinal centers, infiltrating lymphocytes, and reactive lymphoid follicles.
  • EBV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is transmitted through saliva, making it a common cause of infectious mononucleosis.
  • The virus infects B cells, leading to their proliferation and subsequent immune response, resulting in the clinical presentation observed in the patient.
* [Extra Edge]: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

  • EBV is a ubiquitous herpesvirus implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphomas, B-cell lymphomas in patients with T-cell immunosuppression (HIV infection, transplant recipients), and several other cancers.
  • The EBV genome harbors several genes encoding proteins that trigger B-cell signaling pathways; in concert, these signals are potent inducers of B-cell growth and transformation.
  • In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells can rapidly “grow out” as aggressive B-cell tumors.
  • In the presence of normal T-cell immunity, a small fraction of infected patients develops EBV-positive B-cell tumors (Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma) or carcinomas (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: What do we call the sort of immunity to a specific infectious agent that comes after recovery from that infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Active adaptive immunity
Adaptive immunity is a type of immune response that is specific to a particular pathogen.
  • Active adaptive immunity refers to the immune response that develops after an individual is exposed to a pathogen and recovers from the resulting infection. During this process, the immune system produces memory cells that "remember" the pathogen and can mount a rapid and effective response if the individual is exposed to the same pathogen again in the future.
  • It involves the activation of lymphocytes, such as B cells and T cells, which recognize and respond to specific antigens on the surface of the pathogen.
  • This type of immunity is acquired over time, either through natural exposure to a pathogen or through vaccination.
  • This is why individuals who have had certain infections, such as chickenpox or measles, are typically immune to those diseases for the rest of their lives.
  • Passive adaptive immunity, on the other hand, refers to the transfer of pre-formed antibodies or immune cells from one individual to another. This type of immunity is typically short-lived and does not involve the activation of the recipient's own immune system. An example of passive adaptive immunity is the transfer of maternal antibodies to a developing fetus during pregnancy.
  • Innate immunity, both active and passive, is the first line of defense against pathogens and is not specific to a particular pathogen. It includes physical barriers, such as the skin and mucous membranes, as well as cellular and molecular components of the immune system that recognize and respond to common features of pathogens.
    Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 83.

questions.text: Fever, jaundice, and conjunctival hyperemia are observed in a farmer who has been working in a rice field with bare feet in standing water. Which of the following serological tests must be done to determine the condition's cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Microscopic agglutination test

The given features are suggestive of Weil’s disease caused by Leptospira. Among the given options, the Microscopic agglutination test is the appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Leptospirosis can present with a wide range of symptoms, from mild flu-like illness to severe manifestations such as jaundice, renal failure, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
    • Symptoms typically appear 5-14 days after exposure to the bacteria (Leptospira spp.).

  • Risk Factors and History:

    • Patients with a history of exposure to contaminated water (e.g., floodwaters, recreational activities in lakes or rivers), contact with animals (especially rodents, livestock), or occupations involving such exposures (e.g., farmers, sewage workers) are at higher risk.
    • A detailed history of travel, activities, and animal contact is important for clinical suspicion.

  • Laboratory Tests:

    • Serology: Serological tests are commonly used for diagnosis. These include enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), microscopic agglutination test (MAT), and indirect hemagglutination assay (IHA). These tests detect antibodies (IgM and IgG) produced in response to Leptospira infection.
    • PCR: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays can detect Leptospira DNA in blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) during the early phase of illness, typically within the first week of symptoms.
    • Culture: Culture of Leptospira bacteria from blood or urine is challenging and less commonly used due to slow growth and technical requirements.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 390.

questions.text: What will happen if several screening tests are conducted Consecutively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Increased positive predictive value 

Conducting several screening tests consecutively is also known as testing in series. It increases Positive predictive value.
 

Testing in Series

  1. Sequential Testing: In series testing, individuals undergo multiple tests in a predefined order. For a patient to be classified as positive in a series of tests, they must test positive on all tests in the sequence.

  2. Effect on Sensitivity and Specificity: The overall sensitivity and specificity of the series of tests are affected by the sensitivity and specificity of each individual test and their combined performance.

Positive Predictive Value (PPV)

  • Definition: PPV is the probability that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease.
  • Calculation: PPV depends not only on the sensitivity and specificity of each test but also on the prevalence of the disease in the population being tested.
  • Impact of Series Testing:

    • PPV tends to increase with sequential testing in series. This is because as more tests are added, the likelihood of false positives decreases, especially if individual tests have less than perfect specificity.

    • The formula for PPV when tests are conducted in series is:

      PPV=True Positives in the entire series/Total number of Positive results in the entire series

Negative Predictive Value (NPV)

  • Definition: NPV is the probability that individuals with a negative test result truly do not have the disease.
  • Calculation: NPV depends on the sensitivity and specificity of each test, as well as the prevalence of the disease.
  • Impact of Series Testing:

    • NPV generally improves with sequential testing in parallel or simultaneous testing. This is because the probability of correctly ruling out disease (true negatives) increases as more tests confirm a negative result.

    • The formula for NPV when tests are conducted in series is:

      NPV=True Negatives in the entire series/Total number of Negative results in the entire series

Reference: Medical Biostatistics, 3rd edition, Page no 56.

questions.text: What will happen if we increase the sample size in a study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Results will be more reliable

Larger studies provide stronger and more reliable results because they have smaller margins of error and lower standards of deviation. Therefore, on increasing sample size, results will be more reliable.

NOTE:
The standard error is dependent on the size of the samples: standard error is inversely related to the square root of the sample size, so that the larger n becomes, the more closely will the sample mean represent the true population mean. This is the mathematical reason why the results of large studies or surveys are more trusted than the results of small ones—a fact that is intuitively obvious.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: Which form of disinfection involves cleaning a cholera patient's faeces?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Concurrent

CONCURRENT DISINFECTION :-
  • Concurrent disinfection is the immediate disinfection of all contaminated articles and body discharges during the course of the disease
  • It is done immediately, then and there during the course of illness.
  • It includes cleaning the isolation unit daily with effective disinfectant
TERMINAL DISINFECTION :-
  • Terminal disinfection means disinfection of the patients unit and all the articles used after the discharge, transfer or death of the patient who was suffering from the contagious disease
  • It is done after the patient has recovered from a communicable disease or has died after suffering from a communicable disease.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 275.

questions.text: Which of these is true about herd immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Develops by clinical & subclinical infections
 
  • Herd immunity is the protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunisation.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of a population is immune to a disease.
  • It develops by occurrence of clinical and sub clinical infection in the herd.
  • It is not necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population. The proportion of immune individuals  above which a disease no longer spreads  is called herd immunity threshold.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 117.

questions.text: The recommended pre-exposure prophylaxis schedule for Rabies in high risk individuals like veterinarians is

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for rabies involves administering a series of vaccinations to individuals at risk of exposure to rabies virus, such as veterinarians, animal handlers, and travellers to rabies-endemic areas.
The standard PrEP regimen for rabies vaccination typically involves a 3-dose schedule administered over a period of time.
As per the NCDC - Guidelines for Rabies-pre exposure prophylaxis should be done with two doses on day 0,7 and a booster dose either on day 21/28. (Total 3 doses).

Individuals who have received successful pre-exposure rabies immunization require only two booster doses of the vaccine on days 0 and 3 if exposed to RABV. Administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is not necessary.

questions.text: Which stage of the demographic cycle is characterized by a zero growth rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Fourth stage
 
  • The demographic cycle refers to the different stages of population growth and demographic transition that a country goes through.
  • The model divides population growth into five stages:
  1. Pre-industrial: High birth and death rates, with little to no population growth.
  2. Early expanding: Birth rates remain high, but death rates decline, resulting in rapid population growth.
  3. Late expanding: Birth rates begin to decline, but death rates remain low, resulting in slower population growth.
  4. Low stationary: Birth rates and death rates are both low, resulting in zero population growth.
  5. Decline: Birth rates fall below death rates, resulting in population decline.






Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 554.

questions.text: Identify the fertility indicator that includes women in the reproductive age group.
questions.solution:

  • It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.  
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2-child norm.

questions.text: Which of these is true about cow's milk?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of these is true about Indian reference man and woman?
questions.solution:
Option 1 is correct: Both Indian reference man and woman require 1 gm/kg protein per day.
  • The ICMR recommends that both Indian reference man and woman require a daily protein intake of 1 gm/kg of body weight.
  • This means that a man weighing 60 kg would require 60 gm of protein per day, and a woman weighing 55 kg would require 55 gm of protein per day. 
  • Option 2 is incorrect because the ICMR does not provide a specific recommendation for the daily fat intake of the Indian reference man and woman. However, it is recommended that the diet should contain 20-30% of total calories from fat.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because the ICMR defines the Indian reference man and woman as healthy individuals between the ages of 19 and 39 years, not specifically in the age group of 25-35 years.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because the ICMR does not provide a specific recommendation for the duration of sitting and moving around for the Indian reference man and woman. However, it is recommended that individuals should engage in at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity on most days of the week.
  • A reference man: is

    • Weighs 65 kg with a
    • Height of 1.77 m and
    • BMI of 20.75 and is
    • Free from disease and physically fit for active work.
    • On each working day, he is engaged in 8 hours of occupation which usually involves moderate activity.
    • While not at work, he spends 8 hours in bed, 4–6 hours in sitting and moving about, 2 hours in walking, and in active recreation or household duties.

    A reference woman: is
    • Between 19 and 39 years of age

    • On each working day, she is engaged in 8 hours of occupation which usually involves moderate activity.
    • While not at work, she spends 8 hours in bed, 4–6 hours in sitting and moving about, 2 hours in walking, and in active recreation or household duties.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient who is bedridden is taking medication. The patient manifested the following skin lesion five days after beginning the medication, as indicated in the picture. It is because of-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Deficiency of protein 'C'
 

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a rare but serious complication that can occur shortly after starting warfarin therapy. It is associated with a deficiency of protein C, an important natural anticoagulant protein.

    Mechanism of Warfarin-Induced Skin Necrosis:

  • Role of Protein C:

    • Protein C is a natural anticoagulant that inhibits clotting factors (especially factors V and VIII) in the coagulation cascade.
    • Warfarin initially inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (including factors II, VII, IX, X), which leads to a transient period of decreased anticoagulant proteins like protein C and protein S. This creates a temporary procoagulant state.

  • Timing and Pathophysiology:

    • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis typically occurs within the first few days to weeks of starting warfarin therapy, especially when it is initiated at higher doses without concurrent administration of heparin.
    • In individuals with an underlying deficiency of protein C (either inherited or acquired), this initial procoagulant effect can lead to microthrombi formation in small blood vessels, particularly in the skin.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Patients present with painful, erythematous plaques or patches that rapidly progress to areas of skin necrosis (blackening of the skin due to tissue death).
    • The most commonly affected areas include the breasts, thighs, abdomen, and buttocks.

  • Diagnosis and Management:

    • Diagnosis is clinical and based on the characteristic presentation of skin necrosis in a patient recently started on warfarin.
    • Management involves immediate cessation of warfarin therapy and administration of vitamin K to reverse its effects. Heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin may be used temporarily to bridge until vitamin K levels normalize.
    • Protein C concentrate or fresh frozen plasma (FFP) containing protein C can be administered to replace the deficient protein and restore anticoagulant balance.

  • Prevention:

    • To minimize the risk of warfarin-induced skin necrosis, especially in patients with known protein C deficiency, warfarin therapy should be initiated at lower doses and overlapped with heparin until adequate anticoagulation is achieved.

  • Long-Term Management:

    • Patients who experience warfarin-induced skin necrosis should be managed by a hematologist or thrombosis specialist. They may require alternative anticoagulation strategies, such as direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), which do not affect protein C levels to the same extent.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page no 668.

choices.text: Increasing the absorption of drug in intestine

questions.text: Identify the effect of P-glycoprotein.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 3) Decreasing concentration of drug in brain

P-GLYCOPROTEIN:
  • ATP dependent efflux pump also called Multidrug Resistant protein 1
  • Functions
  1. Biological barrier – Extrudes toxins and xenobiotics ( like chemotherapeutic agents ) out of cells. 
  2. Protect the body from harmful substances by removing drugs absorbed in the intestines back into the gut lumen. 
  3. Maintains the integrity of the blood brain barrier
  4. Excretes drugs from the kidneys and liver into the urine and bile respectively.
Option 3: P glycoprotein maintains the integrity of the blood brain barrier thereby decreasing the drug entry inside brain. This leads to the decrease in drug concentration in the brain. Hence, its the correct option

Other options

Option 1  P-glycoprotein helps in removing drugs absorbed in the intestines back into the gut lumen. Therefore the statement "Increasing the absorption of drug in intestine" is incorrect. 

Option 2  P-glycoprotein increases excretion of drugs from the kidneys into the urine. Hence, option 2 " Decreasing excretion of drug by kidney" is incorrect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 19.

questions.text: What is the rationale behind use of neostigmine in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Increased acetylcholine to act at NM receptors
 
  • Neostigmine is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor and the primary mechanism of action is decreased breakdown of acetylcholine at the motor endplate. Neostigmine indirectly stimulates nicotinic and muscarinic receptors.
  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used mainly to improve muscle tone in people with myasthenia gravis, and also to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants such as rocuronium and vecuronium at the end of an operation. 
  • Inhibition of acetylcholine esterase increases the acetylcholine levels in the synapse that can act on receptors over the large surface area and for longer periods of time, reducing the weakness.
  • It is also used in postoperative and neurogenic ileus and urinary retention, myasthenia gravis, reversal of neuromuscular junction blockade (postoperative).

questions.text: Hypertension is treated with aliskiren. Aliskiren reduces blood pressure because it-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Prevents formation of Angiotensin-1

*ALISKIREN:-
Trials so far have shown that aliskiren reduces hypertensive left ventricular hypertrophy and benefits CHF patients, but its value compared to ACE inhibitors/ARBs as monotherapy and as additional drug remains to be established on the basis of outcome data. Aliskiren reduces albuminuria and has reno protective effect in hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
 
  • It is an example of Direct Renin inhibitor
  • MECHANISM OF ACTION – It blocks the conversion of Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin 1 and the effector chain of RAS is interrupted. While the concentration of renin in plasma is increased by feedback, the plasma renin activity (PRA) is decreased.
  • USE – At present, aliskiren is recommended as an alternative antihypertensive drug (for those who do not respond or do not tolerate 1st line drugs) and in combination with ACE inhibitor/ARB to achieve more complete RAS blockade and greater BP lowering/ cardio protection
  • ADEVERSE EFFECTS – Hyperkalemia, Hypotension, Angioedema
  • CONTRAINDICATIONS – Pregnancy; In patients taking ACE inhibitors and ARBs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 538.

questions.text: The following antiarrhythmic drug and its respective use is correct:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Adenosine in supraventricular tachycardia

Adenosine and Verapamil both can be used in case of SVT but there is following instances Adenosine has advantage over Verapamil-
  • Efficacy equivalent to or better than verapamil.
  • Action lasts < 1 min; adverse effects (even cardiac arrest, if it occurs) are transient.
  • No hemodynamic deterioration. It can be given to patients with hypotension, CHF or those receiving β blockers. Verapamil is contraindicated in these situations.
  • Safe in wide QRS tachycardia (verapamil is unsafe).
  • May be effective in patients not responding to verapamil.
However, adenosine produces transient dyspnea, chest pain, fall in BP and flushing in 30–60% patients; ventricular standstill for few sec or VF occurs in some patients, but resolves quickly. Bronchospasm may be precipitated in asthmatics; verapamil is the drug of choice for such patients.

So, Between Option 2 and Option 4 Adenosine should be chosen as the answer in this question.
Option 1 and 3 Regarding Lidocaine and Quinidine is Untrue.



TRICK TO REMEMBER COMMON ARRYTHMIA AND THEIR DRUGS WHICH ARE FREQUENTLY ASKED:-
 
  • SUPRAVENTRICULAR – Adenosine, Verapamil, Diltiazem, Digoxin
  • VENTRICULAR –Lidocaine, Mexiletine
  • BOTH – Amiodarone, class 1a,1c, Beta blockers

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 581.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated with telotristat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diarrhea induced by carcinoid tumor
 
  • Telotristat is indicated for the treatment of diarrhea associated with carcinoid syndrome.
  • Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can produce excessive amounts of serotonin, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea.
  • Telotristat works by inhibiting the enzyme tryptophan hydroxylase, which is responsible for serotonin production.
  • By reducing serotonin levels, telotristat helps to alleviate the diarrhea symptoms associated with carcinoid tumors.
* Other options:
  • Pheochromocytoma-induced hypertensive crisis (A) is typically managed with alpha-blockers and other medications to control blood pressure.
  • Galactorrhea in pituitary tumor (C) is often treated with medication such as dopamine agonists to reduce the production of prolactin, a hormone responsible for galactorrhea.
  • Myxedema of Hypothyroidism (D) is treated with thyroid hormone replacement therapy to restore the levels of thyroid hormones in the body.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1098.

questions.text: Which of the chelating agent listed  below can be used to treat cystinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Penicillamine

Some points about Cystinuria
  • AR genetic defect
  • Defect in the transepithelial  transport of cystine and other dibasic amino acids in the kidney
  • Stones form due to increase excretion of cystine which is poorly soluble at normal Urine pH.
  • These stones are resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy so Percutaneous surgery or Ureteroscopy are preferred techniques of stone extraction.
  • Medical preventative treatment is by high volume diuresis and urine alkalinization by Sodium Bicarbonate and/or potassium citrate
  • When these methods fail to prevent recurrence or dissolving pre-existing stones, sulfhydryl agents like D-penicillamine or Tiopronin are used which form highly soluble disulfides.
  • Frequent clinical and USG follow up is done to encourage patient compliance and assess efficacy of treatment.

  • Mechanism of Action:

  • Chelation of Cystine:

    • Penicillamine works by forming a stable complex with cystine, which increases its solubility in urine. This reduces the concentration of free cystine in the urine, thereby decreasing the risk of cystine crystal formation and stone development in the kidneys and urinary tract.

  • Reduction in Stone Formation:

    • By chelating cystine, penicillamine helps prevent the aggregation of cystine crystals into stones. This is particularly beneficial for individuals with cystinuria who are prone to recurrent kidney stones.

  • Urinary Excretion:

    • The penicillamine-cystine complex is excreted in the urine, which helps to reduce the overall cystine load in the body.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 498

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with causes of peripheral neuropathy?

  • Isoniazid

questions.text: Which anti-retroviral medication among the following inhibits both C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) and type 5 (CCR5) activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option is 2) Cenicriviroc
 
  • Cenicriviroc is an anti-retroviral medication that inhibits both C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) and C-C chemokine receptor type 5 (CCR5) activity.
  • CCR2 and CCR5 are chemokine receptors that play a role in the entry of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) into host cells.
  • By blocking these receptors, cenicriviroc interferes with the entry of HIV into host cells and helps to control viral replication.

  • Cenicriviroc for the treatment of liver fibrosis in adults with nonalcoholic steatohepatiti

questions.text: Which antidepressant from the list below is an SNRI (selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Duloxetine
 
  • Venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, Levomilnacipran, milnacipran are some SNRIs (Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors).
  • They inhibit 5-HT and norepinephrine reuptake.
  • Used in: Depression, general anxiety disorder, diabetic neuropathy. Venlafaxine is also indicated for social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, PTSD, OCD. Duloxetine is also indicated for fibromyalgia.
  • Side effects: HTN, stimulant effects, sedation, nausea.
* [Extra Edge]: SSRIs Vs SNRIs
 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic medicine among the following works by opening the Cl- channel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tiagabine 
 
  • Tiagabine is an antiepileptic medication that works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of GABA by the GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1) in the brain.
  • By inhibiting GABA reuptake, tiagabine increases the concentration of GABA in the synaptic cleft, leading to enhanced GABAergic neurotransmission.
  • Increased GABA levels can result in the opening of Cl- channels, hyperpolarization of neurons, and overall inhibition of neuronal activity, which can help prevent seizures.
Trick: -
TiaGABINe- meaning GABA reuptake INhibitor



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: Which of the following behaviours is exclusive to opioid receptors of the \(\mu\)[mu] type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pupillary constriction
 
  • Pupillary constriction (miosis) is primarily associated with the activation of opioid receptors of the mu type.
  • When mu opioid receptors are activated by opioid medications or endogenous opioids, they can cause the muscles in the iris of the eye to constrict, resulting in pupillary constriction.
  • This effect is commonly observed with mu opioid agonists, such as morphine and other opioids.
  • Supraspinal analgesia, dysphoria, and constipation can be associated with the activation of both mu (μ) and other opioid receptor types, such as delta (δ) and kappa (κ) receptors.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 507.

questions.text: Select the one that acts for the longest duration-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rosuvastatin

Rosuvastatin are not extensively metabolized by CYP3A4, is excreted unchanged in the urine, greater LDL-CH reduction can be obtained in severe hypercholesterolemia partly due to its longer persistence in the plasma.
  • Rosuvastatin is a statin medication used to lower cholesterol levels.
  • It has a long half-life, which means it stays in the body for a longer duration compared to other statins.
  • The half-life of rosuvastatin is approximately 19 hours, allowing for sustained cholesterol-lowering effects over an extended period.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 684, 685.

questions.text: The following drug cannot be used for the treatment of vomiting:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) H1 histamine agonists
 

H1 antagonists, also known as antihistamines, are commonly used in the treatment of various conditions, including allergies and motion sickness. While they primarily block the action of histamine at H1 receptors, their role in directly treating vomiting is limited. However, they can sometimes be used as part of a broader treatment approach for vomiting in specific situations:

  1. Motion Sickness:

    • H1 antagonists like dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) and meclizine (Antivert) are often used to prevent and alleviate symptoms of motion sickness, which can include nausea and vomiting. They work by exerting antiemetic effects and reducing the symptoms associated with motion-induced nausea and vomiting.

  2. Nausea and Vomiting due to Vestibular Disorders:

    • Certain H1 antagonists, particularly meclizine, can also be used to manage nausea and vomiting associated with vestibular disorders, such as vertigo.

  3. Adverse Effects of Medications:

    • In some cases, medications prescribed for other conditions may cause nausea and vomiting as side effects. H1 antagonists can be used to alleviate these symptoms, although they do not address the underlying cause directly.

  4. Adjunctive Therapy:

    • H1 antagonists may be used as adjunctive therapy in combination with other antiemetic medications to enhance the overall efficacy in managing vomiting. For instance, they may be combined with dopamine receptor antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) or serotonin receptor antagonists (e.g., ondansetron) for better control of nausea and vomiting in certain clinical scenarios.

  5. Pediatric Use:

    • Some H1 antagonists are also used in children to manage motion sickness and associated vomiting, although dosages must be adjusted based on age and weight.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs used in vomiting




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 183.

questions.text: The following cephalosporin has an antipseudomonal activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cefepime
 
  • Antipseudomonal cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a common and often antibiotic-resistant bacterium that can cause severe infections, especially in hospitalized patients and those with compromised immune systems.
  • These cephalosporins have enhanced activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa compared to other cephalosporins. 

  1. Ceftazidime:

    • Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that exhibits potent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is commonly used for severe infections caused by this bacterium, including respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections. Ceftazidime is often used in combination with other antibiotics for more comprehensive coverage.

  2. Cefepime:

    • Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin that also has excellent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is structurally similar to third-generation cephalosporins but has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria, including extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL)-producing organisms. Cefepime is frequently used in hospitals for serious infections, including nosocomial pneumonia, complicated urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
    • Cefepime has enhanced activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa compared to earlier generation cephalosporins.

  3. Ceftolozane/Tazobactam:

    • Ceftolozane/tazobactam is a novel antipseudomonal cephalosporin/beta-lactamase inhibitor combination. It was specifically developed to combat multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa strains. Tazobactam, a beta-lactamase inhibitor, enhances the activity of ceftolozane against beta-lactamase-producing bacteria, including some strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa resistant to other cephalosporins.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs useful in Pseudomonas infection



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 779.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics blocks protein synthesis by interfering with the translocation step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Erythromycin
 
  • Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin and streptomycin, are a class of antibiotics that work by binding to the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.
  • By binding to the ribosome, aminoglycosides interfere with the accurate reading of the mRNA codons during protein synthesis.
  • This interference disrupts the translocation step, which is the movement of the ribosome along the mRNA strand during protein synthesis.
  • Ultimately, the disruption of translocation leads to the inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 801.

questions.text: Which of the following is the only antimalarial medication used to treat malaria effectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Primaquine

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species of Plasmodia, while artemisinins have weak lethal action on early stage but not mature gametes.
A single dose of primaquine is employed immediately after clinical cure of falciparum malaria to kill the gametes and cut down transmission to mosquito.
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication that is primarily used for the prevention and treatment of relapse in certain types of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale.
  • It is the only medication effective against the dormant liver stage of these malaria parasites, preventing the reemergence of the infection.
  •  By eliminating these hypnozoites, primaquine significantly reduces the reservoir of malaria parasites in the population and decreases the transmission of P. falciparum.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Which of the following cancer treatments targets the M-phase only?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Docetaxel
 
  • Docetaxel is a chemotherapy medication that belongs to a class of drugs called taxanes.
  • Taxanes primarily target the M-phase (mitotic phase) of the cell cycle, which is the phase when cells divide and replicate their DNA.
  • Docetaxel works by inhibiting microtubule disassembly during cell division, leading to cell cycle arrest and preventing further cell division.
  • By specifically targeting the M-phase, docetaxel can disrupt the growth and proliferation of cancer cells.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 925.

questions.text: The following is an absolute contraindication for oral contraceptives [OCPs] use:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: DVT.
 
  • The use of oral contraceptives (OCPs) increases the risk of thromboembolic events, including DVT and pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • Women with a history of DVT or other clotting disorders are at higher risk of developing complications if they take OCPs.
  • Therefore, OCPs are absolutely contraindicated in such individuals.
  • Alternative contraceptive methods should be considered for women with a history of DVT or other clotting disorders.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 577.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is associated with branchial cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid
 
  • A branchial cyst is a cystic swelling that arises from the persistence of embryonic branchial clefts or pouches.
  • These clefts are derived from the embryonic pharyngeal arches.
  • The cysts are usually found along the course of these embryonic clefts or pouches.
  • The anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle is associated with the first branchial cleft.

questions.text: The following cause of hemolytic anemia involves IgM in the Pathogenesis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mycoplasma infection
 
  • Mycoplasma infection is associated with hemolytic anemia involving IgM antibodies.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae, a bacteria-like organism, can cause atypical pneumonia and is known to induce the production of cold agglutinins, which are IgM antibodies that bind to red blood cells at low temperatures.
  • The binding of IgM antibodies to red blood cells leads to their destruction and hemolysis, resulting in hemolytic anemia.
  • Other causes of hemolytic anemia involving IgM include infectious mononucleosis (caused by EBV) and certain lymphomas.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 650.

questions.text: The following diad is true regarding the given image and the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bite cells: G6PD deficiency 
 
  • Bite cells and helmet cells are characteristic of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is an inherited enzymatic disorder that leads to red blood cell membrane damage and the formation of Heinz bodies.
  • Bite cells are formed when macrophages in the spleen remove the Heinz bodies from the red blood cells, leaving characteristic "bites" or notches.
  • Therefore, the correct match is Bite cells - G6PD deficiency.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: The following cannot cause the renal pathology is given in the figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diabetes mellitus
 
  • Flea-bitten appearance of the kidney refers to multiple petechial hemorrhages on the renal surface.
  • Conditions associated with this pathology:
    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury due to platelet aggregation and microthrombi formation in renal microvasculature.
    • Malignant hypertension: Severe hypertension leading to arteriolar damage and fibrinoid necrosis in renal arterioles.
    • Infective endocarditis: Infection of heart valves leading to embolic infarctions in the kidney.
  • Diabetes mellitus does not typically cause the flea-bitten appearance of the kidney.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of intestinal fistula in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ileosigmoid

Crohn's disease can cause fistula formation between different parts of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Types of intestinal fistulas in Crohn's disease:
    • Enterocutaneous: Fistula between the intestine and the skin.
    • Ileosigmoid: Fistula between the ileum (part of the small intestine) and the sigmoid colon (part of the large intestine).
    • Gastrocolic: Fistula between the stomach and the colon.
    • Rectovaginal: Fistula between the rectum and the vagina.
  • Among these, the ileosigmoid fistula is the most common in Crohn's disease.
  • Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus.
  • It is characterized by inflammation, ulcers, and scarring of the intestinal walls, which can lead to the formation of fistulas.
  • An ileosigmoid fistula is a connection between the ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and the sigmoid colon (the last part of the large intestine). It can develop as a complication of Crohn's disease when inflammation and ulcers erode through the intestinal walls and create a passageway between the two organs. Symptoms of an ileosigmoid fistula may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloating, and fever. Treatment typically involves surgery to remove the affected portion of the intestine and repair the fistula. 
* [Extra Edge]: Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: The following causes acute respiratory distress syndrome [ARDS] by causing indirect lung injury:

Sepsis is an indirect cause of ARDS, while Fat embolism/Aspiration of gastric contents and Pneumonia are direct causes of lung injury causing ARDS.

questions.text: Which is the main collagen type in a completely healed scar mark?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (1): Type 1 Collagen
 

The main collagen type in a completely healed scar mark is 1. Type 1 collagen.

During the healing process, type 3 collagen is initially laid down in the wound, but as the scar matures, it is gradually replaced by type 1 collagen, which provides greater tensile strength and structural integrity to the healed tissue.

Type of Collagen

questions.text: The following Prostaglandin causes both vasodilatation and vasoconstriction:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PGF2α

Among the four types of prostaglandins mentioned in the question, PGF2α is the only one that causes both vasodilatation and vasoconstriction.
  • PGF2α is produced by the smooth muscle cells of blood vessels and has a potent vasoconstrictive effect. This means that it causes the blood vessels to narrow, which increases the resistance to blood flow and raises blood pressure.
  • However, PGF2α also has a vasodilatory effect on certain blood vessels, such as those in the coronary arteries and the uterus. This means that it causes these blood vessels to relax and widen, which increases blood flow to these areas.
Option 1 PGE2 is primarily a vasodilator, which means that it causes blood vessels to relax and widen.
Option 3 PGI2 (prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation.
Option 4 Thromboxane A2, on the other hand, is a potent vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 200.

Many other tumors in the body show similar morphology as the salivary gland tumors such Pleomorphic adenoma of skin (chondroid syringoma), Adenoid cystic variant adenocarcinoma of endometrium, Warthin's tumor however is seen only in salivary gland.

questions.text: There is an increase in PT and aPTT in-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Liver diseases
 
  • PT (Prothrombin Time) and aPTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) are tests used to evaluate the clotting function of the blood.
  • In liver diseases, the liver's synthetic function is impaired, leading to a deficiency in clotting factors.
  • Decreased levels of clotting factors in the blood result in prolonged PT and aPTT.

* Other options:
 
  • Hemophilia A is a congenital disorder characterized by a deficiency in factor VIII, leading to prolonged aPTT.
  • Hemophilia C is a rare congenital disorder characterized by a deficiency in factor XI, leading to prolonged aPTT.
  • von Willebrand disease (VWD) is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, resulting in prolonged bleeding time and sometimes aPTT.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 455.

questions.text: The following aneuploidy is due to an defective mitosis leading to cells with different chromosome numbers within the same individual.:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Mosaicism
 
  • Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes in a cell.
  • Errors during cell division can lead to aneuploidy.
  • Mosaicism is a type of aneuploidy that occurs due to errors in mitosis, leading to cells with different chromosome numbers within the same individual.
Other options:
  • Uniparental disomy refers to the inheritance of both chromosomes of a homologous pair from a single parent.
  • Monosomy is the presence of only one copy of a particular chromosome.
  • Trisomy is the presence of an additional copy of a particular chromosome.
* [Extra Edge]: Chromosomal Abnormality



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: The type of urinary cast that is positive in urine in a patient of renal parenchymal disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fine granular cast
 
  • Urinary casts are cylindrical structures formed within the renal tubules and are composed of different materials.
  • In renal parenchymal disease, such as glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis, the casts seen in the urine can provide diagnostic clues.
  • Fine granular casts are composed of finely granular material and can be seen in various conditions, including renal parenchymal disease.
* Other options:
  • Coarse granular casts are formed by the precipitation of cellular debris and are typically seen in renal tubular injury.
  • Hyaline casts are transparent and composed of protein and can be found in both normal and pathological conditions.
  • Epithelial casts contain desquamated renal tubular epithelial cells and can indicate severe tubular injury.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2304.

questions.text: Dystrophy calcification can be observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Tuberculoma
 
  • Dystrophic calcification refers to the deposition of calcium in areas of tissue damage or necrosis.
  • It occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium levels and is not caused by systemic calcium imbalances.
  • Tuberculoma is a granulomatous lesion caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • In chronic tuberculosis infection, caseous necrosis and subsequent calcification can occur, leading to dystrophic calcification.
* Other options:
  • Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased serum calcium levels and can lead to metastatic calcification in various tissues.
  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that can cause non-caseating granulomas but is not typically associated with dystrophic calcification.
*[Extra Edge]: Dystrophic Calcification Vs Metastatic Calcification



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 65.

questions.text: The following is a cause of systemic amyloidosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Lymphoma
 
  • Amyloidosis is a group of disorders characterized by the extracellular deposition of abnormal insoluble protein fibrils called amyloid.
  • Systemic amyloidosis refers to the involvement of multiple organs/systems
  • In Lymphoma, an abnormal protein called serum amyloid A (SAA) is produced secondary to chronic inflammation, which can lead to systemic amyloidosis.
* Other options:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma /Alzheimer's disease and Type 2 diabetes mellitus are associated with localized Amyloidosis. 

* [Extra Edge]: Types of Amyloidosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 262.

questions.text: Which of these is least likely associated with Dense deposit renal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lipodystrophy
 
  • Dense deposit renal disease (also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type II) is a rare form of kidney disease characterized by the deposition of abnormal material in the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Dense deposit renal disease is most commonly associated with complement dysregulation.
  • Conditions associated with Dense deposit renal disease:
    • HBV infection: Hepatitis B virus infection can trigger immune complex deposition and complement activation, leading to Dense deposit renal disease.
    • SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus): Autoimmune disease characterized by immune complex formation and glomerular involvement.
    • Cryoglobulinemia: Presence of cryoglobulins (abnormal proteins) in the blood, which can deposit in the kidneys.
  • Lipodystrophy is a disorder characterized by the loss of adipose tissue and is not typically associated with Dense deposit renal disease.
  • Out of the given options, Lipodystrophy is least likely associated with Dense deposit renal disease. Lipodystrophy is a rare disorder that affects the body's ability to produce and store fat. It is not typically associated with kidney disease, including Dense deposit disease. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2341.

questions.text: Which part of the IPC (Indian Penal Code) governs the punishment for intentionally causing great bodily harm with a dangerous weapon?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: 326 IPC

The punishment for intentionally causing grievous hurt with a dangerous weapon is defined in IPC 326.

Section 320 IPC: Grievous hurt definition - Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of twenty days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits. 

The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous:"
  • Emasculation
  • Permanent privation of the sight of either eye
  • Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear
  • Privation of any member or joint
  • Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint
  • Permanent disfiguration of the head or face
  • Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth

questions.text: A photosensitive lesion on the malar area of the patient's face, who is 40 years old, has been brought to the skin OPD. The kind of consent given in this instance is
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Implied consent.

Implied consent refers to a form of consent that is not explicitly expressed but is assumed based on the circumstances and conduct of the individual. Implied consent is often relied upon in situations where explicit consent may not be practical or necessary, such as routine medical examinations or emergency medical treatment.

E.g., patient extends their arm to allow a healthcare professional to take their blood pressure

Option 1: Blanket consent refers to a broad, general consent given by an individual that covers a range of activities or procedures without specifying each one individually. 

E.g., A patient admitted in the ward need not provide consent for blood collection, routine vaccination.

Option 2: Informed consent is a voluntary and explicit agreement given by an individual after being provided with adequate information about the nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives of a particular procedure, treatment, or activity.

E.g., Before undergoing surgery.

Option 3: Expressed consent, also known as explicit consent, is a clear and direct verbal or written agreement given by an individual to authorize a specific action, procedure, or activity. 

E.g., A person signing a document or verbally stating "Yes, I agree" to participate in a research study is providing expressed consent for their involvement.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 32.

questions.text: Identify the type of post mortem finding shown in the given figure.

The above image shows PM staining/Livor Mortis/Suggillation

Option 4: In warm, humid climate body fat hydrolyses into soapy waxy substance and gives off ammoniacal odour which is called Adipocere formation. This process may take weeks to months.

questions.text: How does one differentiate between strangulation and hanging?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: More extensive local damage in strangulation than hanging.

There is more extensive local damage in Strangulation due to force and the struggle between two people. Fracture of hyoid bone is more common in hanging but it can also occur in strangulation, thus among option 1 and 3, option 1 is a better answer.

questions.text: Which of the following situations makes it beneficial to utilize PGE1 right away after birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: TAPVC
 

In the context of Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC), PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1) plays a critical role in the management of newborns with certain types of this congenital heart defect.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC):

TAPVC is a rare congenital heart defect where all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect abnormally to the right atrium or other nearby veins. This results in a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, leading to significant cardiovascular compromise.

Role of PGE1:

  1. Ductal-Dependent Circulation:

    • In some forms of TAPVC, particularly those where the pulmonary veins connect to systemic veins or the right atrium, there may be obstruction or severe restriction of pulmonary venous return to the left heart.
    • Newborns with this type of TAPVC may be dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) for adequate pulmonary blood flow.

  2. Maintaining Ductal Patency:

    • PGE1 is a potent vasodilator that acts to maintain patency (openness) of the ductus arteriosus. This is crucial in neonates with TAPVC who have obstructed pulmonary venous return, as it helps to ensure adequate pulmonary blood flow until definitive surgical repair can be performed.

  3. Preoperative Stabilization:

    • PGE1 is often initiated in newborns suspected or diagnosed with obstructive TAPVC to stabilize their condition and optimize oxygenation while preparations are made for corrective surgery.

  4. Diagnostic Aid:

    • PGE1 infusion can sometimes be used diagnostically in suspected cases of obstructive TAPVC. If there is improvement in oxygenation and hemodynamics with PGE1, it may suggest ductal dependence


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 423,424

questions.text: Which of these is a cyanotic heart disease with increased pulmonary blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Transposition of great arteries [TGA]

In TGA the aorta arises from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle.

Desaturated blood returning from the body to the right side of the heart goes inappropriately out the aorta and back into the body again, whereas oxygenated pulmonary venous blood returning to left side of heart is returned directly to the lungs. Thus systemic and pulmonary circulations act as two parallel circuits.

The left ventricle is larger and contacts with more pressure which leads to increased pulmonary blood flow.









Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 421-423

questions.text: Which is the most common part of GIT involved in Hirschsprung disease?

questions.text: The following is not observed in cystic fibrosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Obstruction of sweat gland ducts

CYSTIC FIBROSIS à ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT TOPICS FREQUENTLY TESTED IN EXAMS:-
  • Autosomal Recessive inheritance
  • Defect in CFTR gene on chromosome 7 (  F508 )
  • Most common lethal genetic disease.
  • PATHOPHYSIOLOGY :- 
  • Normally CFTR encodes ATP gated chloride channel which is responsible for secretion of chloride ions in lungs and gastro intestinal tracts, and reabsorption of chloride ions in sweat glands.
  •  F508 deletion decreases secretion of chloride and water à Increase in intracellular chloride ions results in compensatory increase in sodium and water reabsorption à Thus thick mucus gets secreted in lungs and gastrointestinal tract. Increased sodium reabsorption leads to development of negative transepithelial potential difference.
  • DIAGNOSIS :-
  • Increased chloride ion concentration is Pilocarpine induced sweat test—Diagnostic
  • Increased Immunoreactive Trypsinogen in Newborn screening test
  • CLINICAL FEATURES :-
  • Recurrent Pulmonary Infections ( commonly by Staph aureus – children ; Pseudomonas -- adult )
  • ABPA, Bronchiectasis , Chronic Bronchitis
  • Nasal polyps
  • Pancreatic Insufficiency, Malabsorption , Steatorrhea , deficiency of fat soluble vitamins
  • INFERTILITY – MALES à Due to ABSENCE OF VAS DEFERENS ; FEMALES --. THICK CERVICAL MUCUS [ VV IMP –FREQUENTLY TESTED ]
  • TREATMENT :-
  • Multifactorial
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Aerosolized Dornase Alfa—inhalation route
  • Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy
  • Combination of LUMACAFTOR OR TEZACAFTOR ( corrects misfolded proteins ) with IVACAFTOR ( opens chloride channels )

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 392,393

questions.text: The following conditions does not cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rotor syndrome 

Rotor syndrome, also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin.
  • Rotor syndrome does not cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is caused by an increase in the level of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood, which is usually due to either increased production or decreased clearance of bilirubin.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, on the other hand, is caused by an increase in the level of conjugated bilirubin in the blood, which is usually due to impaired excretion of bilirubin.
  • Hypothyroidism, hemolysis, and physiological jaundice can all cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is decreased clearance of bilirubin due to decreased activity of liver enzymes. In hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin due to breakdown of red blood cells.
  • In physiological jaundice, there is increased production of bilirubin due to immature liver function.
  • Rotor syndrome, on the other hand, is a rare genetic disorder that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is characterized by the accumulation of bilirubin in the liver and blood due to impaired excretion of bilirubin. However, it is important to note that unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may also be present in some cases of Rotor syndrome, but it is not the predominant feature.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 853.
