questions.text: What is the cause of diplopia in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Astigmatism

 
  • Image above is showing a pterygium.  The Pterygium growing on the corneal causes irregular astigmatism and horizontal flattening of cornea leading to diplopia.
  • Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea. It occurs as a response to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet rays, dry heat, etc.
  • A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:
    • Cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
    • Head
    • Body
  • Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism. Diplopia is rare symptom if the pterygium involves the medial rectus.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 207.

questions.text: What kind of hypersensitivity results in phlycten?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.
 
  • Phlyctens are small, white or yellowish nodules that form on the conjunctiva or cornea.
  • They are commonly associated with ocular inflammation, specifically in conditions such as phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.
  • The development of phylectens is primarily mediated by Type-4 hypersensitivity reactions. 
  • Type-4 hypersensitivity or delayed-type hypersensitivity or cell-mediated hypersensitivity: Characterized by the activation of T cells and the release of cytokines.
  • In case of phlyctens, the reaction is typically triggered by an immune response to antigens derived from bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus > Mycobacterium tuberculosis.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: Which symptom does not describe a corneal ulcer brought on by a fungus?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Ulcus Serpens.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. The corneal ulcer appears dry with delicate feathery finger-like extensions. 
Ulcus serpens is a hypopyon corneal ulcer caused by pneumococcus. Hence not seen in this condition.
  • Option 1: The immune ring of Wessely is formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).
  • Option 2: In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon is not sterile. The fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation.
  • Option 3: A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation), as well as multiple, small satellite lesions, may be present.




Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: The following is not true about the causes of cataracts
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Oil-drop cataract is caused by Diabetes.
 
  • Oil-drop cataract refers to the presence of yellowish or brownish, oil-like droplets in the lens. It is not specifically caused by diabetes.
  • The most common cause of oil-drop cataract is galactosemia.
  • In galactosemia, the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens can lead to the formation of oil-drop opacities.
  • While diabetes can contribute to the development of certain types of cataracts, such as posterior subcapsular cataracts and snowflake cataracts, it is not associated with oil-drop cataracts.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 193, 200.

questions.text: What is the most common type of concomitant strabismus?
questions.solution:
The correct is option 2 :Exotropia

 
  • Exotropia is a type of concomitant strabismus where one or both eyes turn outward. It is the most common type of strabismus and can occur in both children and adults.
  • In exotropia, the eyes are misaligned due to a weakness or imbalance of the eye muscles that control eye movement. This can cause double vision, difficulty with depth perception, and eye strain.
  • Convergent squint, also known as esotropia, is another type of concomitant strabismus where one or both eyes turn inward. This condition is less common than exotropia.
  • Paralytic squint is a type of strabismus where the misalignment of the eyes is due to a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the eye muscles. This condition is not as common as exotropia or esotropia.
  • Therefore, based on the information above, it can be concluded that option 2, Exotropia, is the most common type of concomitant strabismus.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 364.

questions.text: Which of the following cells contributes to the development of the retina's inner limiting membrane layer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Muller cells.
 
  • The inner limiting membrane (ILM) is a layer located at the innermost surface of the retina.
  • It is composed of specialized cells and extracellular matrix components.
  • Muller cells (Muller glial cells), play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the retina's inner limiting membrane.
  • Muller cells are a type of glial cell that spans the entire thickness of the retina.
  • They provide structural support, contribute to the blood-retinal barrier, and participate in the formation of the ILM by secreting extracellular matrix components.
Retinal glial cells:





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 419.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the efferent pathway of the light reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Oculomotor nerve.
 
  • The oculomotor nerve, also known as cranial nerve III, is responsible for the motor control of most eye movements, including constriction of the pupil.
  • In the efferent pathway of the light reflex, the oculomotor nerve carries signals from the brain to the muscles that control the pupil's size, causing it to constrict in response to light.
Other options:
While the optic nerve (Option 1) and retina (Option 2) are involved in the afferent pathway of the light reflex, it is the oculomotor nerve that contributes to the efferent pathway by controlling the pupil's constriction.




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 327.

questions.text: What causes dextroelevation during conjugate movement?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Left inferior oblique & right superior rectus.
 
  • Dextroelevation refers to the upward and rightward movement of both eyes during conjugate movement.
  • The correct combination that causes dextroelevation is the left inferior oblique muscle and the right superior rectus muscle.
  • The left inferior oblique muscle helps in upward and leftward movement of the eye, while the right superior rectus muscle helps in rightward movement of the eye.
  • Together, the left inferior oblique and right superior rectus muscles work in a coordinated manner to produce dextroelevation during conjugate eye movement.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1194, 1200.

questions.text: The following is a feature of thyroid ophthalmopathy:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Restriction of eye movement.
 
  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy or thyroid-associated orbitopathy, is an autoimmune condition commonly associated with Graves' disease.
  • It primarily affects the soft tissues and muscles around the eyes, leading to various ocular manifestations like exophthalmos, infrequent blinking and retracted eyelids. 
  • Restriction of eye movement is a characteristic feature of thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • It is caused by inflammation and fibrosis of the extraocular muscles, which can limit the ability to move the eyes freely.
  • Enophlamos and ptosis can be seen with Horner’s syndrome: Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome leading to enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1344, 1345.

questions.text: Which of these is true about sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Injured eye is exciting eye
  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare, but serious, immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that can occur after an eye injury or surgery.
  • It is characterized by bilateral granulomatous uveitis, which means inflammation of the uvea (the middle layer of the eye) that is typically associated with the formation of granulomas.
  • The term "sympathetic" refers to the fact that the inflammation in the second eye occurs as a sympathetic response to the injury in the first eye.
  • Option 1: "Trauma to iris," is generally not a risk factor for sympathetic ophthalmia, indeed Trauma to Ciliary body is usually the triggering factor. Any type of eye injury or surgery can potentially trigger the immune response that leads to sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • Option 2: "Non-granulomatous uveitis," is incorrect because sympathetic ophthalmia is characterized by autoimmune granulomatous panuveitis, not non-granulomatous uveitis.
  • Option 3: "Unilateral," is incorrect because sympathetic ophthalmia always affects both eyes. This is because the immune response that causes the inflammation in the second eye is a systemic response, rather than a local response to the injury in the first eye. The inflammation can occur weeks to months after the initial injury, and it can be severe enough to cause permanent damage to the affected eye if not treated promptly.
  • Option 4: "Injured eye is exciting eye," is correct . The injured eye (exciting eye) is indeed the eye that triggers the immune response that leads to sympathetic ophthalmia, but the inflammation occurs in both eyes, not just the injured eye.


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 506.

questions.text: What is NEXUS criteria in radiology used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Cervical spine injury.
 
  • NEXUS (National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study): Includes the criteria which is used to decide which trauma patients do not require cervical spine imaging.
 
  • Prehospital screening tools, such as the Canadian C-spine Rule or the National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS), provide a means by which patients who have no findings on examination, demonstrate no decreased level of consciousness, and have no distracting injuries can undergo clearance of the spine by clinical means alone.

Trauma patients who do not require cervical spine imaging require all of the following features to be present- 
•    Alert and stable
•    No focal neurologic deficit
•    No altered level of consciousness
•    Not intoxicated
•    No midline spinal tenderness
•    No distracting injury

Mnemonic to remember the criteria- "NSAID":
•    Neurological deficit
•    Spinal tenderness
•    Altered mental status
•    Intoxication
•    Distracting injury



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 400.

questions.text: Which kind of Gustilo and Anderson compound fracture has substantial soft tissue damage and periosteal stripping?
questions.solution:
Gustilo-Anderson classification

  • grade 1: clean wound <1 cm in length
  • grade 2: wound 1-10 cm in length without extensive soft-tissue damage, flaps or avulsions
  • grade 3: extensive soft-tissue laceration (>10 cm) or tissue loss/damage or an open segmental fracture
    • open fractures caused by
    • farm injuries
    • injuries requiring vascular intervention
    • fractures that have been open for 8 hours prior to treatment

Grade 3 injuries can be further subdivided by the degree of periosteal and vascular injury and soft tissue loss:

  • grade 3a: adequate periosteal coverage of the fracture bone despite the extensive soft-tissue laceration or damage
  • grade 3b
    • extensive soft-tissue loss, periosteal stripping and bone damage
    • usually associated with massive contamination
    • will often need further soft-tissue coverage procedure (e.g. free or rotational flap)
  • grade 3c: associated with an arterial injury requiring repair, irrespective of degree of soft-tissue injury 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 21

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injuries can affect a girl with the left elbow deformity depicted in the figure?
questions.solution:
• The girl in the figure has a left elbow deformity, which is likely cubitus valgus (also known as "gunstock deformity").
  • This deformity can cause stretching or compression of the ulnar nerve, which runs along the inside of the elbow. Late onset ulnar nerve injury can occur due to chronic compression or stretching of the nerve, known as Tardy Ulnar nerve palsy. 
  • Symptoms may include numbness or tingling in the ring and little fingers, weakness in the hand, and difficulty with fine motor tasks.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 104

questions.text: The deformity depicted in the picture below occurs for which nerve injury?
questions.solution:
This image is showing partial Claw hand sign which is seen in Ulnar nerve damage.

Ulnar nerve supplies
1. 3rd and 4th Lumbricals 
2. Palmar and Dorsal interossei

3/4th lumbrical are required for PIP and DIP extension at 4th/5th digits, and 4th/5th digit flexion at MCP joint.
Hence, ulnar nerve damage will lead to flexion at 4th/5th digit PIP and DIP joints, and extension at  4th/ 5th digit MCP joints leading to partial ulnar claw hand.




Note: The image given is not of Benediction(Pope) sign. In Benedict sign (which occurs due to median nerve damage) - there is loss of 1st and 2nd lumbricals (which helps in 2/3rd digits MCP Flexion) - leading to extension at index/middle finger MCP joint. But since 3/4th lumbrical are spared - there is flexion at 4/5th digit MCP joint. 
The main difference is at 4/5th digit MCP joint - In ulnar claw hand - 4/5th digit MCP joint would be extended; while 4th/5th digit MCP in benedict sign(median nerve injury) would be flexed. 





Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: What is the earliest clinical manifestation of rickets?
questions.solution:
• The earliest clinical manifestation of rickets is the softening of the skull bones.
  • This occurs because the skull bones are the first bones to form in the fetus, and they continue to grow rapidly in the first few months of life.
  • If there is a deficiency of vitamin D during this period, the skull bones become soft and pliable, which can lead to a condition called craniotabes. This is characterized by a softening of the skull bones, which can be felt as a depression or a thinning of the bone.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 310

questions.text: Identify the radiological feature not associated with scurvy?
questions.solution:
Correct option 4:Widening of metaphysis 
  • Widening of metaphysis is a feature of rickets.
  • In radiology, scurvy is characterized by several features, including ring epiphysis, Pelken's spur, and Frankel's line.
  • These features are seen due to the disruption of normal bone growth and mineralization caused by vitamin C deficiency.
  • Ring epiphysis refers to the radiolucent zone seen in the metaphysis of long bones, which appears as a ring-like structure.
  • This feature is associated with scurvy and is caused by the failure of mineralization at the growth plate. Pelken's spur is a radiological feature seen in scurvy, which appears as a bony outgrowth from the metaphysis.
  • It is caused by the deposition of unmineralized osteoid tissue in response to the vitamin C deficiency. Frankel's line is a radiological feature seen in scurvy, which appears as a radiolucent line at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of long bones.
  • This feature is caused by the failure of mineralization at the junction due to vitamin C deficiency.
  • Therefore, option 4, i.e., Widening of metaphysis, is not associated with scurvy, and this is the correct answer.
   



Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 538,539

questions.solution:

questions.text: The Trendelenburg test is used to evaluate:
questions.solution:
• The Trendelenburg test is a physical examination maneuver used to evaluate the strength of the hip abductor muscles, specifically the gluteus medius muscle.
  • This muscle is responsible for stabilizing the pelvis when standing on one leg, which is important for maintaining balance during activities such as walking, running, and jumping.
  • During the Trendelenburg test, the patient is asked to stand on one leg while the examiner observes the position of the pelvis. If the hip abductor muscles are weak, the pelvis will drop on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating a positive Trendelenburg sign.


   


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 348

questions.text: Which of the following describes an indirect appendicitis indication on a USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Mesenteric lymphadenopathy
 
  • Indirect findings on ultrasound (USG) can sometimes suggest the presence of appendicitis.
  • Mesenteric lymphadenopathy, or enlargement of lymph nodes in the mesentery near the appendix, can be observed on USG and may indicate an inflammatory process in the appendix.
  • Other direct findings, such as increased wall thickness or an appendicolith, are more specific for diagnosing appendicitis.
  • Ultrasound findings of acute appendicits:
    • Non-compressible, dilated appendix
    • Thickened appendix wall
    • Presence of appendicolith (fecalith)
    • Peri-appendiceal fluid collection
    • Hypoechoic (dark) appearance of the appendix
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: A female patient in her 60s complains of burning & itching in one breast. The following image is visible following a clinical evaluation. The following statements about the ailment are all accurate, with the exception of which one:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) S-100 antigen positive on immunostaining
 
  • The clinical evaluation and the image suggest Paget's disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer that affects the nipple and areola.
  • While Paget's disease of the breast is associated with underlying invasive breast cancer in most cases, immunostaining for S-100 antigen is typically negative in Paget's cells. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.
  • Other accurate statements include external signs if underlying invasive cancer, presentation with a mass in more than 50% of cases.
  • Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Fig: Nipple erosion in early Paget’s disease

questions.text: Chronic venous insufficiency has been documented in a patient over the age of 65. The patient is presenting the following leg lesion. what is the CEAP classification's clinical stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: C6
 
  • The CEAP classification system is used to describe the clinical severity of chronic venous insufficiency.
  • Stage C6 indicates the presence of venous ulcers, which are non-healing wounds associated with chronic venous hypertension and impaired venous return.
  • Other stages in the CEAP classification include C0 (no visible or palpable signs of venous disease) to C5 (advanced skin changes without ulceration).



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text: The following is not true about Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Examination shows reduced TSH level.
 
  1. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: An autoimmune disorder, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland.
  2. Oncocytic metaplasia is a characteristic feature of Hashimoto's thyroiditis but not pathognomonic (definitive) for the condition. It is a histological finding of large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  3. Hashimoto's thyroiditis can present with hyperthyroidism during the early phases of the disease. This is known as "Hashitoxicosis" or "painless thyroiditis".
  4. Examination reveals elevated TSH level due to reduced thyroid hormone production as the feedback inhibition is removed. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

questions.text: The following statement is correct regarding pheochromocytoma:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Vascular invasion may occur in benign lesions.
 
  • Pheochromocytoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor.
  • It originates from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia.
  • Most commonly, pheochromocytomas arise in the adrenal medulla.
  • While usually benign, they can exhibit vascular invasion, mimicking malignant characteristics.
  • Pheochromocytoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN-2), not MEN-1.
  • Approximately 10% of cases are malignant, not 40%.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2976, 2977, 2979.

choices.text: Patey's surgery is done for the treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with a slowly expanding, painless swelling above the mandibular angle. Swelling moves about and has variable consistency. Regarding the swelling, all of the following are accurate, except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Has uniphasic cellular pattern
 
  • The given clinical scenario and image depict a likely case of parotid tumor (option A), likely to be a pleomorphic adenoma.
  • The parotid tail is the most common site (Option B) for parotid gland tumors to occur. It is the portion of the parotid gland that extends backward and wraps around the mandible.
  • However, the swelling in this case does not exhibit a uniphasic cellular pattern.
  • A uniphasic cellular pattern refers to the appearance of cells in the tumor, and it is not observed in this scenario.
  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation) (option C).
  • Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion, direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Which is the most common benign tumor of the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mixed cell parotid neoplasm
  • The most common benign tumor of the salivary gland is a mixed cell tumor, also known as pleomorphic adenoma, because of its dual origin from epithelial and myoepithelial elements. It is the commonest of all salivary gland tumors constituting up to two-thirds of all salivary gland tumors and is most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • This tumor accounts for approximately 60-70% of all salivary gland tumors.
  • It typically arises from the parotid gland, which is the largest salivary gland located in front of the ear.
  • Mixed cell tumors are composed of both epithelial and mesenchymal cells, which give rise to the diverse histologic appearance and varied clinical behavior.
  • They are slow-growing and painless, and usually present as a painless, mobile mass that has been present for months or years.
  • Histologically, mixed cell tumors are characterized by a mixture of ductal epithelial cells, myoepithelial cells, and stromal cells.
  • The epithelial cells form duct-like structures, while the myoepithelial cells are spindle-shaped and surround the epithelial cells.
  • The stromal cells are responsible for the production of the myxoid or chondroid matrix which gives the tumor its characteristic rubbery consistency.
  • Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for mixed cell tumors, and the prognosis is generally favorable with a low rate of recurrence.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: How does one classify gall bladder carcinoma extending to the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: T3
 
  • The correct classification for gall bladder carcinoma extending to the liver is T3. T3 indicates that the tumor has invaded nearby structures, such as the liver or any other extrahepatic organ.
  • T1 indicates a small tumor confined to the gall bladder without invasion into surrounding structures.
  • T2 classification indicates involvement of the serosa, which is the outermost layer of the gall bladder.
  • T4 classification indicates invasion into adjacent structures beyond the liver.

* Gall bladder TNM staging:



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1517.

choices.text: Distorted folds reach up to the edge of ulcer

questions.text: Which of the following does not distinguishes between benign and malignant gastric ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct option 4:Presence on lesser curvature
 
  • Option 1 is correct because it describes a characteristic feature of malignant gastric ulcers. Malignant gastric ulcers are more likely to have irregular, distorted folds that extend up to the edge of the ulcer. This is because the cancerous cells in the ulcer disrupt the normal architecture of the stomach lining. In contrast, benign ulcers usually have smooth, regular folds around the edges of the ulcer.
  • Option 2, Carman's meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers
  • Option 3, Kirklin complex is a radiological feature seen in malignant gastric ulcers.  Malignant gastric ulcers are more commonly present at the greater curvature of the stomach and show a presence of kirklin complex with a positive carmen meniscus sign.
    The Kirklin complex is a combination of the Carman meniscus sign associated with a radiolucent semicircular zone surrounding the elevated ridge of the ulcer.
  • This complex is seen in cases of gastric adenocarcinoma on barium studies.
    The Carman meniscus sign describes the lenticular shape of barium in cases of large and flat gastric ulcers, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen. It usually indicates a malignant ulcerated neoplasm.
  • Option 4, presence on lesser curvature, is not specific to either benign or malignant gastric ulcers and does not distinguish between the two.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1165.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the colon's appearance on the barium study, as seen in the illustration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ulcerative colitis
 
  • The barium enema shows the lead pipe appearance seen in ulcerative colitis.
  • Ulcerative colitis diffusely involves the mucosa and submucosa of the colon.
  • There is a complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of the colon, and the organ appears smooth-walled and cylindrical; giving it the appearance of a lead pipe.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1163.

questions.text: What is the most common location for splenunculi?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hilum of spleen
 
  • Splenunculi, also known as accessory spleens, are most commonly found in the hilum of the spleen. The hilum is the area where blood vessels enter and exit the spleen.
  • Splenunculi can occasionally be found in other locations, such as the greater omentum, but the hilum of the spleen is the most frequent site.
  • Other locations:
      • Splenic Hilum
      • Tail of the Pancreas
      • Gastrosplenic Ligaments
      • Lienorenal Ligaments
      • Wall of the Stomach
      • Wall of the Intestines
      • Greater Omentum
      • Mesentery
      • Pelvis or Scrotum (rarely observed)
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1221.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles contains the "gateway of tears"/Killian Dehiscence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Inferior constrictor of the pharynx

Killian Dehiscence: This refers to a weakness or defect in the posterior wall of the pharynx, specifically between the inferior constrictor muscle and the cricopharyngeus muscle.
This area is located in the hypopharynx (part of the pharynx just above the esophagus) and is susceptible to the formation of a diverticulum or pouch called a Killian's or Killian-Jamieson diverticulum.
This diverticulum can form due to increased pressure during swallowing, leading to a herniation of the mucosa through the weak spot causing Zenker's Diverticulum.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464e.153,1464e,162,712

questions.text: Which of the following carcinomas has historically used the Gleason score as a grading system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Prostatic carcinoma
 
  • The Gleason score is primarily used for grading prostatic carcinoma. It assesses the architectural patterns of prostate cancer cells and assigns a score based on their differentiation.
  • The Gleason score helps predict the aggressiveness and prognosis of prostate cancer, with higher scores indicating a higher grade and more aggressive tumor.

Patterns 1 and 2 are no longer defined in the 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score system.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1535.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary glands is the source of deep plunging ranula?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sublingual gland.
 
  • A ranula is a type of mucous retention cyst in the floor of the mouth.
  • It results from the obstruction of salivary gland ducts, causing the accumulation of saliva.
  • Deep plunging ranulas are a specific type of ranula that are located in the submandibular space.
  • They are caused by a leakage of saliva from the sublingual gland into the submandibular space.
  • The sublingual gland, located under the tongue, can lead to deep plunging ranulas when its saliva leaks into the submandibular space.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 833, 834.

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Treatment of choice for stage-T2 cancer is intravesical chemotherapy 
 
  • Smoking is the most important risk factor (option A) for developing urinary bladder carcinoma. Risk factors:

  • The most common histological variant of urinary bladder carcinoma is transitional cell carcinoma (option B).
  • Muscle invasion is seen in T2 stage (option C), which indicates infiltration into the muscular layer of the bladder wall.
  • Intravesical chemotherapy is not the treatment of choice for stage T2 cancer; radical cystectomy (surgical removal of the bladder) is usually recommended.

questions.text: The following is not a feature of superficial second-degree burns:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Heal with scarring
  • Superficial second-degree burns, also known as partial-thickness burns, involve the epidermis and the upper dermis layer of the skin.
  • These types of burns are characterized by redness, pain, and the presence of blisters.
  • However, they do not typically result in scarring as the damage is limited to the top layers of the skin, and the skin is able to regenerate new cells to replace the damaged ones.
  • The healing process of superficial second-degree burns typically takes around 2-3 weeks, and the skin may peel or itch during this time.
  • However, scarring is not a common outcome of this type of burn unless the burn is very deep or becomes infected. In such cases, the burn may progress to a full-thickness burn, which can result in scarring.
  • Therefore, option 3 is the correct answer as healing with scarring is not a typical feature of superficial second-degree burns.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 321.

questions.text: What would be the investigation of choice for obstructive jaundice due to gallstone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: MRI
 
  • MRI provides detailed images of the biliary system, including the bile ducts, gallbladder, and liver, allowing for the visualization of any obstructions or abnormalities.
  • MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) is a specific MRI technique used to evaluate the biliary system.
  • Other imaging modalities, such as ultrasound or CT scan, may also be used in the evaluation of obstructive jaundice, but MRI with MRCP is considered the most comprehensive and accurate imaging technique for this condition.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1495.

questions.text: At the 36th week of her pregnancy, a multipara lady is experiencing a low platelet count, elevated serum transaminases, and mild hemolysis. What course of action should be taken next?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3:Delivery of the baby
  • The symptoms described in the question - low platelet count, elevated serum transaminases, and mild hemolysis - are indicative of a serious medical condition called HELLP syndrome, which is a variant of preeclampsia.
  • This condition can be life-threatening for both the mother and the baby.
  • The only definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome is delivery of the baby, which is why option 3, "Delivery of the baby," is the correct course of action.
  • Intravenous corticosteroids (option 1) may be used to manage some of the symptoms of HELLP syndrome, but they are not a definitive treatment and do not address the underlying condition.
  • Wait and watch (option 2) is not a safe option as HELLP syndrome can progress rapidly and cause serious complications.
  • Intra-amniotic corticosteroids (option 4) are not recommended for the treatment of HELLP syndrome.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 699.

questions.text: What is the most common symptomatic manifestation in menopausal women?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hot flashes

  • The menopause transition is associated with various symptoms, which can interact to produce morbidity.
 
  • Vasomotor symptoms are the most commonly reported, but vaginal dryness/dyspareunia, sleep difficulties and adverse mood changes have all been shown to worsen as women approach menopause.

questions.text: Which type of FIGO fibroid classification is a submucosal fibroid assigned to if it protrudes less than 50% into the uterine cavity?
questions.solution:
• The FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) fibroid classification system is used to describe the location of uterine fibroids. It has four types, and submucosal fibroids are assigned to Type 0 or Type 1, depending on their degree of protrusion into the uterine cavity.
 

  • Type 0: A pedunculated submucosal fibroid entirely within the endometrial cavity, with no myometrial involvement.

  • Type 1: A submucosal fibroid with ≥50% of its volume in the endometrial cavity and <50% within the myometrium.

  • Type 2: A submucosal fibroid with <50% of its volume in the endometrial cavity and ≥50% within the myometrium.

  • Type 3: A fibroid completely within the myometrium but abutting the endometrium without extending into the endometrial cavity.

  • Type 4: A fibroid entirely within the myometrium, not in contact with the endometrium or serosa.

  • Type 5: A subserosal fibroid with ≥50% of its volume within the myometrium and <50% extending outside the uterine serosa.

  • Type 6: A subserosal fibroid with <50% of its volume within the myometrium and ≥50% extending outside the uterine serosa.

  • Type 7: A pedunculated subserosal fibroid, attached to the uterus by a stalk.

  • Type 8: A fibroid located in an ectopic position (e.g., in the cervix, broad ligament, or parasitic fibroids not involving the myometrium)




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 129.

DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 226.

questions.text: Which of these are the most common ovarian tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Epithelial tumors
  • Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors, accounting for approximately 80-90% of all ovarian tumors.
  • These tumors arise from the surface layer of the ovary, which is composed of epithelial cells.
  • Epithelial tumors are further classified into different subtypes based on their histology, such as serous, mucinous, endometrioid, and clear cell tumors.
 
  • Germ cell tumors are rare tumors that arise from the germ cells of the ovary and account for only 5% of all ovarian tumors. These tumors are more common in younger women and are usually benign. However, some malignant germ cell tumors can also occur.
 
  • Sex cord-stromal tumors and fibrous stromal tumors are also rare types of ovarian tumors that arise from the supporting tissue of the ovary. Sex cord-stromal tumors account for only 1% of all ovarian tumors and can produce hormones such as estrogen and testosterone.
 
  • Fibrous stromal tumors, also known as fibromas, are benign tumors that arise from the connective tissue of the ovary.

questions.text: The following is not a part of the Spielberg's criteria:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Normal ovaries
Diagnosis of ovarian ectopic 
The Spielberg criteria are essential for confirmation of early ovarian pregnancy: 
a) fallopian tube at the affected site must be intact 
b) the gestational sac must occupy the normal position of the ovary 
c) the gestational sac must be connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament 
d) ovarian tissue must be located in the sac wall, which is essential for confirmation of early ovarian pregnancy

choices.text: Total cell number is normal in asymmetric IUGR
Symmetric IUGR is due to extrinsic cause

questions.text: Which of these is true for intrauterine growth retardation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 2 :Total cell number is normal in asymmetric IUGR
  • Asymmetric IUGR is a type of growth restriction where the fetus has a smaller than normal abdominal circumference, but the head circumference is relatively normal.
  • This type of growth restriction is usually due to chronic placental insufficiency, which means that the placenta is not providing enough nutrients and oxygen to the fetus.
  • As a result, the fetus redistributes blood flow to the brain and heart at the expense of other organs, resulting in a smaller abdomen.
  • In asymmetric IUGR, the head circumference is relatively normal because the brain is prioritized for growth and development.
  • However, the body is relatively smaller due to the lack of nutrients and oxygen. Therefore, the total cell number is normal in asymmetric IUGR.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because it states that the head becomes smaller in asymmetric IUGR, which is not true. The head circumference is relatively normal in asymmetric IUGR.
  • Option 3 is also incorrect because symmetric IUGR is not due to an extrinsic cause. Symmetric IUGR is a type of growth restriction where the fetus has a proportionally small head and body. This type of growth restriction is usually due to intrinsic factors such as chromosomal abnormalities or congenital infections.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 534-536.

questions.text: Which of the following makes induction of labour less likely to be successful?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 4. Primipara woman
  • Several factors are considered as predictors of induction failure such as:
  • Bishop’s score <6, nulliparity, gestational age < 41 weeks, maternal age > 30 years, pregnancy complicated by preeclampsia, premature rupture of membranes (PROM), isolated oligohydramnios, gestational diabetes, and hypertension.
  • Primiparous women are those who are giving birth for the first time. In such women, the cervix is usually less favorable for induction of labor, as it is less likely to be effaced and dilated.
  • Therefore, induction of labor in primiparous women is associated with a higher risk of failure and increased likelihood of requiring a cesarean section.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 486, 487.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Examiner of vagina and cervix is done post delivery to look for any cervical and vaginal tears using Sims posterior vaginal wall speculum.

Uses of Sim's speculum are: 
 
  • Gynecological Examinations: It is used during routine pelvic exams to visualize the vaginal walls and cervix.
  • Procedures: Sim's speculum can be employed in procedures such as Pap smears, biopsies, or the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Labor and Delivery: It may also be used during labor to assess the progress of cervical dilation.

Sim's speculum is valued for its ability to provide a clear view of the vaginal and cervical areas, facilitating various gynecological assessments and procedures.






Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 528.

Correct option: 2. Mullerian Agenesis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Stein-Leventhal syndrome is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Decreased fasting insulin levels

Stein-Leventhal syndrome is another name of PCOS. 

Primary diagnostic features of human PCOS: 
1. Hyperandrogenism: 
-Acene
-Hirsutism 
- LH hypersecretion 
2. Disrupted menstrual cycles
Associated with: 
-Infertility 
-High rates of miscarriage 
3. Polycystic ovaries 
Polycystic ovaries 
Additional symptoms associated with human PCOS:
4. Metabolic disturbances 
Associated with: 
-Insulin resistance 
-Glucose intolerance

-Hyperlipidemia 
-Type 2 diabetes

Due to insulin resistance, there is increased fasting insulin levels in PCOD affected women.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314, 315.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used solution for cardioplegic arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Potassium solution.
 
  • Cardioplegic arrest is a technique used to stop the heart during surgery. It is done by injecting a solution into the coronary arteries that stops the heart from beating.
  • The most commonly used solution for cardioplegic arrest is a potassium solution.
  • Potassium solution causes temporary arrest of the heart's electrical activity, leading to reversible cardiac arrest.
  • Stopping the heart's contractions allows surgeons to work on a motionless and bloodless heart during the procedure.
  • To provide a motionless field for the surgeon, the heart is arrested in diastole by the administration of a potassium enriched cardioplegia solution. Cessation of myocardial electromechanical activity is the single most important step in reducing the heart’s metabolism.
  • Potassium-induced arrest alone reduces the heart’s myocardial oxygen consumption by 90%.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page no 1759.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman was seen with a history of dysphonia, dysphagia, impaired vision, and growing limb weakening. The patient's chest X-ray displays the following picture. The most likely finding is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Thymoma.
 
  • The chest X-ray shows a mass in the anterior mediastinum, which is the area of the chest between the lungs. This is a common finding in thymomas, which are tumors that arise from the thymus gland.
  • Thymomas can cause various symptoms such as dysphonia, dysphagia, impaired vision, and limb weakness.





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 70, 71.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 992.

questions.text: Symptoms of a 50-year-old male patient include palpitations, dizziness, and weariness. The ECG strip displays the image below. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Ventricular premature complex.

The ECG strip displays a premature ventricular beat (VPC), originating from the ventricles.
VPCs are frequent and typically not harmful, but they may indicate underlying heart conditions like heart disease or cardiomyopathy.

Criteria of ECG for ventricular premature complex (VPC):
  • Premature beat that originates in the ventricles.
  • QRS complex is wider than 0.12 seconds.
  • There is no P wave preceding the QRS complex.
  • The QRS complex is usually bizarre in appearance.
  • The T wave is usually inverted.
  • The VPC may be followed by a compensatory pause


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1915-1917.

questions.text: A patient with palpitations is brought to the emergency room. The following image can be seen on the ECG recording. What medication is preferred to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lignocaine
 
  • The ECG shows a regular rhythm with a wide QRS complex, indicating ventricular tachycardia (VT).
  • VT is a serious arrhythmia requiring immediate treatment.
  • In a hemodynamically stable patient amiodarone, lidocaine, and procainamide can be used to treat the condition
  • Preferred medication: Lignocaine
  • In hemodynamically unstable patients, electrical cardioversion is done.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1913.

questions.text: A patient has syncope, palpitations, and hypotension all of a sudden. The patient's ECG displays the picture below. What medical intervention does the patient require?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: DC cardioversion.
 
  • In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves, (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
  • Electrical cardioversion is done if the patient is hemodynamically unstable (as in this case scenairo where the patient has hypotension and syncope) or if PSVT does not response to any of the other methods mentioned above.
Management includes:
  • Vagal maneuvers    
  • Intravenous Adenosine
  • Intravenous β blockers (esmolol, metoprolol)
  • Intravenous non-DHP calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem)
  • Electrical cardioversion (if hemodynamically unstable or unresponsive to other methods)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: In the case of a pontine lesion affecting the right medial lemniscus, which of the following sensations will be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Left sided tactile sensations
 
  • A pontine lesion affecting the right medial lemniscus will result in the impairment of sensory information from the left side of the body.
  • The medial lemniscus decussates (crosses over) in the medulla. This means that the right medial lemniscus carries sensory information from the left side of the body, and the left medial lemniscus carries sensory information from the right side of the body.
  • The person will experience a loss of tactile sensations (fine touch, vibration, and proprioception) on the left side of their body due to the disruption in the transmission of sensory signals through the right medial lemniscus.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page No 387,388,389

choices.text: Infection with campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause
Typically there is an areflexic ascending paralysis
Most common cranial nerve involved is optic nerve causing blindness

questions.text: The following statement is not correct regarding  Guillain-Barre syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Most common cranial nerve involved is optic nerve causing blindness.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. 
  • Typical presentation: Progressive weakness and areflexic ascending paralysis that typically starts in the legs and ascends to the arms and trunk. 
  • Most common cause: Infection with Campylobacter jejuni.
  • Complications: Respiratory failure may occur due to muscle weakness affecting breathing.
Optic nerve involvement causing blindness is NOT a common feature of GBS. GBS involves lower brainstem cranial nerves like, VII, IX, X etc.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501, 3502.

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding a disturbance in thyroid function?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: There is increased cholesterol in hypothyroidism.
 
  • Thyroid hormones regulate metabolism. Hypothyroidism results from insufficient thyroid hormone production, causing a slowed metabolism, weight gain, fatigue, and reduced heart rate.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is often weight gain and increased cholesterol levels.
  • Hypothyroidism may cause constipation, but not diarrhea.
  • Palpitations and tachycardia are characteristic of hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

questions.text: Which of these is characteristic of serum-ascites albumin gradient-high ascites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CHF
 
  • The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is a measure used to differentiate the causes of ascites (fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity).
  • A high SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) is typically associated with portal hypertension.
  • Conditions associated with a high SAAG include liver cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and congestive heart failure (CHF).
  • CHF leads to elevated venous pressure, which can cause fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity (ascites).


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 323.

questions.text: Which of the following species can cause the appearance of white blood cells without organisms in urine during a urinary tract infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: GU Tuberculosis
 
Sterile pyuria is the persistent finding of white cells in the urine on routine and microscopy but no growth within 48 hours on culture and sensitivity. Most common cause of sterile pyuria is genitourinary tuberculosis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, 23rd edition, Page no 1165.

choices.text: Age more than 55 years at the time of admission
Serum LDH more than 400 IU/L during initial 48 hours

questions.text: The following is true regarding Ranson's criteria for prognosis in acute pancreatitis:
questions.solution:
Age >55 years at the time of admission is a criteria for Ranson score in Acute Pancreatitis.





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1272.

choices.text: Percentage of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in venous blood
Central venous oxygen saturation can be used

questions.text: Which of the following statements about mixed venous oxygen saturation is untrue?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Can be measured by pulse oximetry.
 
  • Pulse oximetry is a noninvasive method of measuring oxygen saturation in arterial blood.
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SVO2) cannot be measured by pulse oximetry because it measures oxygen saturation in arterial blood.
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation ( SvO2 ) is the O2 saturation of blood at the proximal pulmonary artery. It has been a frequently monitored variable in critically ill patients, since it reflects the average O2 saturation of the blood returning from the body to the right heart, weighted by the respective regional blood flows.
  • The measurement of venous O2 saturation can be performed intermittently by co-oximetry of blood sampled from the distal tip of a pulmonary artery catheter (SvO2) or a central venous catheter (SCVO2).
  • Central venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2) can be used as an alternative to assess tissue oxygenation.
  • SvO2 is commonly measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter inserted into the pulmonary artery.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1305-1307.

questions.text: The Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is not diagnosed using which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Gastrin stimulation test.
 
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) causes excessive production of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates stomach acid production. This can lead to ulcers in the stomach and duodenum.
  • Gastrin stimulation test is not used for ZES diagnosis due to potential false-positive results in conditions like chronic kidney disease.

The diagnosis of ZES is made using a combination of tests, including:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2453, 2454.

questions.text: A stroke with abrupt onset has struck a 65-year-old hypertensive male patient. He has been identified as a patient with a stroke in the superior division of middle cerebral artery distribution following tests. Which of the following clinical characteristics is not possible for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Wernicke's aphasia.
 
  • Wernicke's aphasia is not possible for this patient with infarct of superior division of middle cerebral artery distribution. 
  • Wernicke's aphasia is typically associated with a lesion in the posterior part of the left temporal lobe, specifically in Wernicke's area, which is responsible for language comprehension. It is supplied by inferior division of MCA.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: A stroke affecting the middle cerebral artery can lead to visual deficits, including homonymous hemianopia.
  • Option 2: A stroke in the middle cerebral artery distribution can cause weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body (contralateral hemiplegia) due to its involvement with the motor cortex.
  • Option 4: Gerstman syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by a combination of four symptoms: agraphia (difficulty writing), acalculia (difficulty with mathematical calculations), finger agnosia (inability to identify fingers), and left-right disorientation. It is typically associated with lesions in the dominant parietal lobe

Distribution of MCA:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3326.

questions.text:
Which class of antibodies is most frequently linked to autoimmune pancreatitis?
1. IgG1
2. IgG2
3. IgG3
4. IgG4
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: IgG4
 
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis is associated with the class of antibodies known as IgG4.
  • IgG4-related disease is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis due to infiltration of tissues by IgG4-positive plasma cells.
  • Elevated levels of IgG4 antibodies are commonly observed in autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP1) and serve as an important diagnostic marker for the disease.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2664, 2666.

questions.text: The following is not a clinical feature of CREST syndrome in scleroderma:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Butterfly rash on face 

CREST is the most common form of limited scleroderma, which means that it affects the skin and internal organs, but not the lungs or heart.

It includes:
  • C- Calcinosis cutis
  • R- Raynaud's phenomenon
  • E- Esophageal dysmotility (causing Dysphagia, GERD)
  • S- Sclerodactyly (causing Claw fingers)
  • T- Telengiectasia

CREST is a subset of scleroderma. It is an acronym for the following clinical features:



However, a butterfly rash on the face is not a characteristic feature of scleroderma. Butterfly rash (malar rash) is typically associated with Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2771, 2778.

questions.text: MALToma is positive for the following marker:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: CD 20.
 
  • MALTomas are low-grade B-cell lymphomas that typically arise in the stomach.
  • They are positive for pan B cell markers such as CD19, CD20 ,CD 22 ,CD79a marker, which is a surface protein that is found on a subset of B cells.
  • Negative for CD5,CD10,CD23.





Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 777.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following is associated with a favourable/good prognosis in AML?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (3) Translocation (15:17)
 
  • Prognosis in AML is influenced by various factors, including age/TLC/FAB subtype and genetic abnormalities.
  • Translocation (15:17) refers to the fusion of the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene on chromosome 15 and the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARα) gene on chromosome 17- resulting in PML-RARA fusion gene formation. 
  • This translocation results in subtype of AML called acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) - also M3 subtype in the FAB classification
  • APML has a excellent prognosis, with high response rates to treatment (~ 90-95% overall survival) which includes all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and As2O3 (Arsenic trioxide) given as differentiating agents. 

Other options
  • Age <1 year i.e infantile AML is associated with a bad prognosis. Infantile Leukaemia typically tends to have t(4;11) involving MLL gene translocation which confers chemotherapy resistance and poor prognosis. 
  • Total leukocyte count >1 Lac/mm3 (100,000/mm3) is a high leukocyte count and can be associated with a higher risk of complications; hence associated with a poor prognosis
  • Deletion 5q is a chromosomal abnormality found in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) which can then transform into secondary AML.  Secondary AML has poor prognosis.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 811.

questions.text: The following is not true regarding lung carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Scar carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma
 
  • Scar carcinoma is type of adenocarcinoma. Scar carcinoma is a type of lung cancer that originates around peripheral scars in the lung. Scarring in the lung can result from a variety of infections, injuries, and lung diseases. 
  • Therefore, option 4 is not true and is the correct answer.
  • Option 1 is correct because adenocarcinoma is actually the most common type of lung carcinoma, accounting for approximately 40% of cases.
  • Option 2 is true because squamous cell carcinoma is typically centrally located and can cause obstruction of the bronchi, leading to symptoms such as coughing and shortness of breath.
  • Option 3 is also true because small cell carcinoma is a highly malignant type of lung cancer that tends to grow and spread rapidly, making it difficult to treat.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 717.

choices.text: Obliteration & fusion of foot processes of podocytes

questions.text: Light microscopy finding in membranous glomerulonephritis-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diffuse capillary wall thickening
 
  • Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) is a type of glomerular disease characterized by the immune complex deposition in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • On light microscopy, membranous glomerulonephritis is characterized by Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along the peripheral capillary loops is seen by light microscopy on renal biopsy; this thickening needs to be distinguished from that seen in diabetes and amyloidosis.
  • The subepithelial spikes appear as irregular, finger-like projections extending into the capillary lumen when viewed under electron microscopy.
  • These spikes are formed by the accumulation of immune complexes, predominantly IgG and complement C3, along the outer aspect of the GBM.
  • These spikes can cause thickening and distortion of the GBM, leading to impaired filtration and the development of nephrotic syndrome.

Fig: The light microscopic appearance of membranous nephropathy in which the capillary loops are thickened and prominent, but the cellularity is not expected to be increased.

* Other options:
 
  • Obliteration and fusion of foot processes of podocytes are characteristic findings in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).
  • Subepithelial Spikes are seen in MGN but in Electron Microscopy.
  • Subendothelial hump is observed in post-infectious glomerulonephritis (PIGN).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chronic reflux disease
 
  • Chronic pyelonephritis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the renal parenchyma and renal pelvis, usually caused by recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • The most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis is chronic reflux disease, also known as vesicoureteral reflux.
  • In vesicoureteral reflux, there is abnormal retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys during micturition.
  • This condition predisposes the kidneys to recurrent UTIs, which can lead to chronic inflammation and scarring of the renal tissue.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: Which of the following exhibits a predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Common bile duct stone
 
  • Hyperbilirubinemia refers to increased levels of bilirubin in the blood.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is characterized by increased levels of conjugated bilirubin.
  • The common bile duct stone can cause obstruction of the bile flow, leading to the accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.
* Other options:
  • Physiological jaundice is a transient condition in newborns and is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Breast milk jaundice is a condition that occurs in breastfed infants and is also associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Hypothyroidism can lead to impaired bilirubin conjugation but is not associated with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2560.

choices.text: Copper deposit in Descemet's membrane of the cornea

questions.text: The following is not a correct statement regarding Wilson's disease:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: It is an autosomal dominant disorder.
 
  • Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder, not an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • The deposition of copper in the basal ganglia can result in neurological manifestations, such as movement disorders, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive impairment.
  • One of the characteristic features of Wilson's disease is the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings (copper deposits accumulation in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea).
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to the rupture of Descemet's membrane.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3235, 3236.

questions.text: Which of the following bleeding conditions shows an elevated aPTT with a normal PT?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: SLE.
 
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the blood.
  • In SLE, the aPTT is often prolonged due to the presence of lupus anticoagulant, which is an antiphospholipid antibody that interferes with the clotting process and leads to a tendency for increased bleeding. 
  • However, the PT remains normal because lupus anticoagulant does not affect the extrinsic pathway, which is measured by PT.

  • Cirrhosis → Prolonged PT and aPTT (due to decreased synthesis of coagulation factors).
  • SVC obstruction → Does not cause aPTT/PT abnormalities; it leads to venous congestion.
  • SLE → Lupus anticoagulant (LA) prolongs aPTT due to interference with phospholipid-dependent coagulation tests. However, paradoxically, LA is associated with thrombosis rather than bleeding.
  • Hypothyroidism → Can cause mildly prolonged aPTT due to decreased factor production, but it is not a primary cause of isolated aPTT prolongation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 456, 2741, 2749.

questions.text: Which of the following bleeding conditions shows an elevated aPTT with a normal PT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hemophilia A
 
  • The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and prothrombin time (PT) are tests used to evaluate the clotting function of blood.
  • Hemophilia A is a congenital bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of clotting factor VIII.
  • Hemophilia A is characterized by an elevated aPTT (indicating a defect in the intrinsic pathway) and a normal PT (indicating an intact extrinsic pathway).

Other options:
 
  • Liver diseases, such as cirrhosis, can lead to abnormalities in both aPTT and PT due to impaired synthesis of clotting factors.
  • Parahemophilia is a rare bleeding disorder characterized by a deficiency of clotting factor V can lead to abnormality in both aPTT and PT. 
  • Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by low platelet counts and can affect both aPTT and PT.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: The following is not a pathological feature of Lichen planus:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Munro's microabscess
Neutrophil predominant micro abscess (Munro microabscess) is seen in Psoriasis.

Lichen planus:
  • Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. 
  • Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, wedge-shaped thickening of the granular layer (responsible for Wickham striae), and compact hyperkeratosis.  
  • Degenerating basal epidermal cells (due to CD8+ Cell-mediated basal cell destruction) are known as colloid bodies (cytoid/Civatte bodies), which may appear singly or in clumps - Characteristic of LP
  • Basal melanocytes may fall into the dermis (pigment incontinence).
  • The rete ridges may have a sawtooth appearance and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max-Joseph spaces.
  • In active LP, a bandlike infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.13, 37.14, 37.3

choices.text: Defect in the formation of disulfide bonds

questions.text: The following is not a feature of Netherton syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Autosomal dominant inheritance
 
  • Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of cornification caused by mutations in the serine protease inhibitor of Kazal type 5 gene (SPINK5), which encodes a serine protease inhibitor expressed in epithelial and mucosal surfaces
  • Hair shaft analysis of NS patients finds a reduced number of S-S disulfide bonds in cortical fibers.
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata or bamboo hair is characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. It is seen in Netherton's syndrome. It is also called golf-tee or ball and socket appearance 
  • Bamboo hair presents with atopy, recurrent skin infections, and an increased risk of skin cancer. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.53, 68.3

questions.text: The following is implicated in the pathogenesis of toxic epidermal necrolysis [TEN]:
questions.solution:
The correct option is (1).
  • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.
  • SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).
  • The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are Carbamazepine, lamotrigine, allopurinol, oxicam, NSAIDs, phenytoin, sulfa drugs, etc. 
  • The majority of the Carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis CBZ-SJS/TEN are associated with HLA-B*15:02.
  • HLA-B57 and HLA-B58 have not been consistently associated with an increased risk for SJS/TEN
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.14

questions.text: As seen in the picture, a 9-year-old boy has skin blemishes. Lesions have a long history of spontaneously disappearing and reappearing. What is the effective diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pityriasis alba
 
  • The above scenario of a hypopigmented patches is suggestive of pityriasis alba.
  • It is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature. It is seen in the age group of 3-16 years. 
  • Lesions have scaling and are usually not well marginated. In children, the lesions are often confined to the face and are most common on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin.
  • It is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.25

questions.text: The following is not associated with acanthosis nigricans:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Addison’s disease

Acanthosis nigricans is associated with Cushing’s syndrome, not Addison’s disease.
  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by the symmetrical darkening of the skin of intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.
  • Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in malignancies, especially those of the gastrointestinal tract, acromegaly, and Cushing's syndrome.
  • Other conditions associated with it include obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, hypothyroidism, obstructive sleep apnea, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The condition is managed by dietary and lifestyle modifications. Individual components of the syndrome also need to be addressed by the use of statins, antihypertensives, or hypoglycemic agents.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 87.2

questions.text: The following is not associated with exfoliative dermatitis:
questions.solution:
• Eczematous Dermatitis: Includes atopic dermatitis and contact dermatitis (both allergic and irritant).

  • Psoriasis: Generalized psoriasis, especially pustular psoriasis.

  • Drug Reactions: Adverse effects from medications like antibiotics, anticonvulsants, or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

  • Fungal Infections: Such as tinea (ringworm) affecting large areas of skin.

  • Viral Infections: Infections like herpes simplex or viral exanthems.

  • Autoimmune Diseases: Conditions like SLE or dermatomyositis.

  • Lymphoma and Other Malignancies: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma can present with exfoliative dermatitis.

  • Nutritional Deficiencies: Deficiencies in zinc or essential fatty acids.

  • Seborrheic Dermatitis: Severe cases can lead to widespread scaling and redness.

  • Environmental Irritants: Exposure to harsh chemicals or extreme sunburn



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.31,147.23

questions.text: A 50-year-old man claims that there is an odorous scent everywhere that isn't actually there. The most typical location for a lesion would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: TEMPORAL LOBE
 
  • The given clinical vignette describes a condition called PHANTOSMIA. This is a type of Olfactory hallucination where an odorous scent is perceived in the absence of identifiable stimulus.
  • These can also be described as olfactory hallucinations.
  • These are commonly seen in TEMPORAL LOBE EPILEPSY or certain brain tumors like GLIOBLASTOMA.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 343.

questions.text: What can be a poor prognostic factor for a patient of Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: INSIDUOUS ONSET

The following table depicts the different prognostic factors of Schizophrenia:-


A few most important points to remember about Schizophrenia are:-
  • Timeline: - Onset for more than or equal to 6 months with more than 1 month of active symptoms over the past 6 months.
  • It is a profound functional impairment characterised by positive negative cognitive symptoms.
  • Positive – hallucinations delusions bizarre behaviour
  • Negative – Anhedonia apathy diminished functioning
  • Cognitive – diminished memory and attention, reduced ability to understand
  • Diagnosis – Requires ≥ 2 active symptoms with ≥ 1 of DELUSION, HALLUCINATION, and DISORGANISED SPEECH. The active symptoms include Delusion, Hallucination, Disorganised speech, Disorganised or catatonic behaviour, negative symptoms.
  • It is characterised by increased suicidal tendencies.
  • Associated with increased serotonergic activity.
  • Brain imaging findings may show ventriculomegaly.
  • Subtypes :-
    1. PARANOID – Associated with delusion and hallucination
    2. CATATONIC – Motor function disturbance
    3. SIMPLE 
    4. HEBEPHRENIC – disorganised behaviour and poor contact with reality.
  • Treatment – Atypical antipsychotics like Risperidone

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 318.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment of OCD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: SERTRALINE
The drug of choice for the treatment of OCD is SSRI.

The different examples of SSRI include Sertraline, Escitalopram, Fluoxetine, Fluvoxamine, Paroxetine.

Imp points to remember about OCD:-
•            The common symptoms seen in OCD are Contamination (most common) > Pathological doubt (second most common) > Intrusive thoughts > Symmetry
•            Defence Mechanisms in OCD – Displacement, Undoing, Reaction formation, Inhibition, Isolation of affect (DURII)

Management:
  • DOC – SSRI; Antipsychotic drugs like Clomipramine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole can be given in SSRI Resistant cases.
  • Psychotherapy of choice- Exposure and Response prevention included in CBT



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 489.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: Breast cancer is more common in women with the following personality type:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Type C
 
  • According to the research conducted by Dr. R. Grossarth-Maticek, breast cancer is more common in women with Type C personality.
  • Type C personality is characterized by introversion, passivity, and a tendency to suppress emotions.
  • These individuals often have difficulty expressing their emotions and tend to internalize their stress, which can lead to chronic stress and weakened immune system.
  • Chronic stress can lead to the development of cancer by suppressing the immune system's ability to detect and destroy cancer cells. Therefore, Type C personality is considered a risk factor for breast cancer.
  • On the other hand, Type A personality is characterized by competitiveness, time urgency, and high levels of stress.
  • Type B personality is characterized by a laid-back attitude and low levels of stress.
  • Type D personality is characterized by negative emotions such as anxiety, depression, and social inhibition. While these personality types may have their own set of health risks, they are not specifically associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.
Online Resources: Pelosi AJ. Personality and fatal diseases: Revisiting a scientific scandal. J Health Psychol. 2019 Mar;24(4):421-439. doi: 10.1177/1359105318822045. Epub 2019 Feb 22. PMID: 30791726; PMCID: PMC6712909.
