questions.text: Which of the given statements is incorrect regarding Assist control ventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Can cause respiratory acidosis.
 
  • Assist control ventilation (ACV) is a mechanical ventilation mode providing a set tidal volume (VT) to the patient.
  • It allows patients to trigger breaths at their own respiratory rate, promoting spontaneous breathing (option 3).
  • This mode ensures the patient receives a minimum VT while allowing them to breathe spontaneously.
  • ACV aims to maintain adequate ventilation and prevent respiratory acidosis (not cause it) by ensuring proper CO2 exhalation and balanced pH. 
  • An increase in tidal volume can help improve ventilation and decrease PCO2 in patients with inadequate alveolar ventilation (option 2).
  • Increasing the FiO2 can help increase the oxygen saturation in the patient's blood (option 4).


Reference: Mora Carpio, Andres L. and Jorge I. Mora. “Assist-Control Ventilation.” StatPearls, StatPearls Publishing, 24 April 2023. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28722886/

Mora Carpio AL, Mora JI. Assist-Control Ventilation. [Updated 2023 Apr 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441856/

questions.text: Only the soft palate is visible while evaluating a patient's mouth openness prior to surgery. What is mallampati grade for the test?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. III
 
  • The Mallampati classification system is used to assess the difficulty of intubation by evaluating the visibility of specific structures in the oral cavity.
  • Grade III is assigned when only the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible.
  • This grade suggests potential difficulty in intubation due to a reduced view of the laryngeal structures and limited access to the trachea.
  • A higher Mallampati grade indicates a more difficult intubation, with Grade 1 being the easiest and Grade 4 being the most challenging.





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1379.

choices.text: Muscle relaxant of choice in crush injury patients

questions.text: The following statement is true for succinylcholine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Shortest-acting muscle relaxant
 
  • Succinylcholine, also known as suxamethonium, is a neuromuscular blocking agent that acts as a depolarizing muscle relaxant.
  • It binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction and causes depolarization of the muscle fiber.
  • Succinylcholine has a rapid onset of action and a short duration of action, making it the shortest-acting muscle relaxant available.
* [Extra Edge]: Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants



* Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant although it is the shortest acting (6-11 minutes).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

choices.text: Isosbestic points of oxygenated and reduced hemoglobin are 940 nm and 660 nm

questions.text: Select the statement that is incorrect regarding pulse oximetry:
questions.solution:
Heart rate can be measured with pulse oximeter.
  • Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive method of measuring the oxygen saturation (SpO2) in arterial blood.
  • It measures the absorption of light by hemoglobin in the blood, which varies depending on whether the hemoglobin is carrying oxygen or not.
  • The pulse oximeter uses two wavelengths of light, typically 660 nm and 940 nm, to measure the oxygen saturation.
  • The ratio of the absorption of these two wavelengths is used to calculate the SpO2.
  • Isosbestic points of oxygenated and reduced hemoglobin are  940 nm and 660 nm as mentioned in option 2.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because pulse oximetry can also measure heart rate by detecting changes in blood volume during each pulse. 


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1301, 1302.

questions.text: Which inhalational anaesthetics cause the most cardiac depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Halothane
 
  • Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic that has been used in the past but is now less commonly used due to safety concerns.
  • Halothane is known to have a significant depressive effect on cardiac function, including a negative inotropic effect (reduction in contractility), which can lead to decreased cardiac output.
  • It also reduces systemic vascular resistance and can cause arrhythmias.
  • Nitrous oxide, in particular, has minimal cardiac depressant effects and is often used as an adjunct in anesthesia.
  • Desflurane increases cardiac contractility but is irritant in nature.
  • Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice with cardiac compromise.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 406.

choices.text: Can be treated by head low position
Crystalloids are not useful for prevention of hypotension

questions.text: Which of the given options is not true (false) for post-spinal anesthesia hypotension?
questions.solution:
• Post-spinal anesthesia hypotension is a common complication characterized by a decrease in blood pressure after spinal anesthesia. (Hence, option 1 is a true statement)
  • It is caused by sympathetic blockade and vasodilation, which leads to reduced systemic vascular resistance.
  • A number of measures for the prevention and treatment of spinal block-induced hypotension are used in clinical practice, such as preloading with crystalloid and/or colloid infusion (Hence, option 4 is a false statement and the answer) , wrapping of lower limbs with compression stockings or bandages, administering an optimal dose of local anaesthetic.
  • In post-spinal anesthesia hypotension; tachycardia is followed by bradycardia (hence, option 2 is correct).


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1442.

questions.text: What is the landmark of radial nerve block at wrist?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: 2-3 cm proximal to radial styloid.
 
  • Radial nerve block at the wrist is a regional anaesthesia technique used to provide anaesthesia and analgesia to the hand and forearm.
  • The radial nerve can be blocked by injecting local anaesthetic proximal to the radial styloid process.
  • The injection site is typically 2-3 cm proximal to the radial styloid, just above the distal radius bone.
  • By blocking the radial nerve, sensory and motor innervation to the hand and forearm can be temporarily interrupted, providing pain relief and allowing for various surgical procedures.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 783, 792, 864.
"Durrani MI, Dasgupta S. Radial Nerve Block. [Updated 2022 Nov 28]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532951/

questions.text: The following is not a feature of malignant hyperthermia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) There is hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis 
 
  • Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a potentially life-threatening condition triggered by certain anesthetic agents, such as volatile inhalational agents (e.g., halothane, sevoflurane) and the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine.
  • It is characterized by a hypermetabolic response of skeletal muscles, leading to increased body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other manifestations.
  • There is no hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis associated with malignant hyperthermia.
* Other options:
  • Succinylcholine can trigger malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals. The release of intracellular calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscles is a key event in the pathophysiology of MH.
  • Rhabdomyolysis, the breakdown of muscle tissue, can occur in malignant hyperthermia, leading to the release of myoglobin into the bloodstream and subsequent myoglobinuria.
  • Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for treating malignant hyperthermia. It acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle cells.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 241.

questions.text: Which of the following skull views shows the Mcgrigor-Campbell lines?

questions.text: What is the most common site of idiopathic Basal ganglia calcification?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Globus Pallidus.

Idiopathic Basal Ganglia Calcification (Fahr's disease) : Rare neurological disorder characterized by abnormal calcium deposition in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia.
 
  • Calcification is most commonly reported in the globus pallidus.

choices.text: Good affinity for nitrogen and oxygen in a reduced state
Tc-99m sulfur colloid is used for the reticuloendothelial system

questions.text: The following is not true about Technetium-99m scan:
questions.solution:
The statement that is not true about Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) scan is:

3. Good affinity for nitrogen and oxygen in a reduced state

Here's why:

  1. Uses γ-rays: This is true. Technetium-99m is a gamma-emitting isotope and is widely used in nuclear medicine for imaging, because it emits gamma rays that can be detected by a gamma camera.

  2. Tin chloride as a reducing agent: This is true. Tin chloride (SnCl) is commonly used as a reducing agent to convert Tc-99m from its +7 oxidation state (pertechnetate) to its +4 oxidation state (which is needed for labeling certain radiopharmaceuticals).

  3. Good affinity for nitrogen and oxygen in a reduced state: This is not true. Technetium-99m, particularly in its reduced +4 state, generally forms coordination compounds with sulfur and not with nitrogen or oxygen. It has a stronger affinity for sulfur-containing compounds, which is why Tc-99m sulfur colloid is used in imaging the reticuloendothelial system (liver, spleen, and bone marrow).

  4. Tc-99m sulfur colloid is used for the reticuloendothelial system: This is true. Tc-99m sulfur colloid is indeed used for imaging the reticuloendothelial system, which includes organs like the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

So, statement 3 is the incorrect one.




Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 102-110.

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used radionuclide particle for lymphoscintigraphy?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Tc-99m sulfur colloid. It is taken up by the macrophages hence is used in visualization of RES system. 

Lymphoscintigraphy:
  • Nuclear medicine technique to visualize from a site of radiopharmaceutical injection.
  • regional lymphatic drainage
  • mapping sentinel lymph nodes 
  • Tc-99m sulfur colloid particles are used as they enter lymphatic channels and travel to lymph nodes, where they are engulfed by macrophages.

Reference: Radswiki T, Elfeky M, Shah V, et al. Tc-99m sulfur colloid. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-12394
Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 103, 115.

questions.text: The middle lobe of the right lung has undergone consolidation. On a chest X-ray, which cardiac border may be completely obscured?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Right heart border.
 
  • The middle lobe of right lung is in direct contact with right heart border. 
  • Therefore, right middle lobe consolidation due to any underlying etiology will result in obscuration of right heart border. This is known as silhouette sign. 
  • Similarly, consolidation in right and left lower lobe will result in obscuration of right and left domes of diaphragm respectively. 





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 40.

questions.text: Which fascia runs along the cremasteric muscle in the scrotum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Fascia from internal oblique 
 
  • The cremaster muscle is a thin layer of muscle that covers the testis and spermatic cord in the scrotum.
  • It is responsible for raising the testis in response to cold temperatures. The cremasteric muscle is covered by a fascia that is derived from the fascia of the internal oblique muscle. This fascia is called the cremasteric fascia.
  • It is derived from the fascia of the internal oblique muscle of the abdominal wall.
  • The fascia from the internal oblique muscle runs along the cremasteric muscle in the scrotum.

  


 

Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice 42 nd Edition Page No 1298
